The iMac Pro is my computer when I’m at my desk; the iPad Pro is my computer everywhere else.</p>\n<p>I don’t want to use this space to debate the strengths and weaknesses of the iPad and the Mac. For a long time, I’ve been “Team Both”—someone who uses both devices to get work done and sees the strengths and weaknesses in both. But something that happened to me this week did remind me that those who suggest that it’s the Mac that has all the power and the iPad that’s wanting are definitely a few steps behind.</p>\n<p>Since I do so much writing on my iPad, I’ve tried to build up some tools to make the process a bit easier. One of them, <a href=\"https://sixcolors.com/post/2018/12/friday-shortcuts-posting-content-using-ancient-web-apis/\">which I detailed back in 2018</a>, lets me post directly to my ancient Movable Type blog system from within my iOS text editor.</p>\n<p>While Dan and I are the only people likely to use that Movable Type shortcut (unless Daring Fireball’s John Gruber really gets into iPad productivity), another shortcut I built for my writing could be useful in a few contexts beyond my own.&#8230;</p> <p>This story is for Six Colors members only. <strong><a href=\"https://sixcolors.com/subscribe/\">Become a member</a></strong> to get access to exclusive stories, podcasts, and community..</p>","descriptionType":"text/html","publishedDate":"Thu, 30 Apr 2020 22:46:37 +0000","feedId":1506,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"aafdcf350b519488a791a2834e1b7751","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"Jason Snell","publishedOrCreatedDate":1598293144264},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 02:19:04","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 02:19:04","title":"Fun With Charts: When Apple was in the red","link":"http://two.wordpress.test/post/2020/02/fun_with_charts_when_apple_was_in_the_red/","description":"<p>So I was researching <a href=\"https://sixcolors.com/post/2020/01/fun-with-charts-apples-turnaround-decade/\">my chart about Apple in the 2000s</a> when I came across <a href=\"https://www.apple.com/newsroom/2003/01/15Apple-Reports-First-Quarter-Results/\">a remarkable historical document</a> on Apple’s website:</p>\n<blockquote><p>\n  CUPERTINO, California—January 15, 2003—Apple® today announced financial results for its fiscal 2003 first quarter ended December 28, 2002. For the quarter, the Company posted a net loss of $8 million, or $.02 per share. These results compare to a net profit of $38 million, or $.11 per diluted share, in the year-ago quarter. Revenues for the quarter were $1.47 billion, up 7 percent from the year-ago quarter, and gross margins were 27.6 percent, down from 30.7 percent in the year-ago quarter. International sales accounted for 43 percent of the quarter’s revenues.\n</p></blockquote>\n<p>That was 17 years ago. And it was the last time Apple lost money in a fiscal quarter.</p>\n<p>Apple actually lost money in both fiscal 2001 and 2002. Our memory of Apple’s history involves Jobs returning in 1997, the iMac in 1998, and the iPod in 2001, leading the company into a glorious future. The fact is, after a few years of a return to profitability, Apple went in the hole in 2001 and 2002. The iPod began to pick up speed in 2003, and after two years of modest profits, things started growing and then exploded with the release of the iPhone.</p>\n<figure><img src=\"https://i2.wp.com/sixcolors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/apple-annual-profits-6c.png?ssl=1\" alt=\"\" data-image-w=\"\" data-image-h=\"\" class=\" jetpack-broken-image\" data-recalc-dims=\"1\"><figcaption></figcaption></figure><p>Here’s another fun note from that 17-year-old press release:</p>\n<blockquote><p>\n  Apple shipped 743 thousand Macintosh® units during the quarter, about even with the year-ago quarter.\n</p></blockquote>\n<p>Apple generated $1.1 billion in revenue off of those 743,000 Macs. Apple doesn’t release Mac unit sales figures anymore, but on its most recent fiscal quarter, Apple generated $7.2 billion in Mac revenue. So while the story of Apple from 2003 to today is really a story of the iPod and then the iPhone, in the background the Mac business increased by a whole lot.</p>\n<p>And Apple doesn’t lose money anymore.</p>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Wed, 12 Feb 2020 16:45:18 +0000","feedId":1506,"bgimg":"https://i2.wp.com/sixcolors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/apple-annual-profits-6c.png?ssl=1","linkMd5":"e67860d06f046b07966b39130c1575fd","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn31@2020_3/2020/08/24/18-19-09-059_75ee2c4200e7c5c4.webp","destWidth":1360,"destHeight":818,"sourceBytes":26376,"destBytes":26376,"author":"Jason Snell","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i2.wp.com/sixcolors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/apple-annual-profits-6c.png?ssl=1":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn31@2020_3/2020/08/24/18-19-09-059_75ee2c4200e7c5c4.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598293144630},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 02:19:04","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 02:19:04","title":"Unpacking, hacking, and cracking a Power Mac G3","link":"http://two.wordpress.test/post/2020/03/unpacking_hacking_and_cracking_a_powermac_g3/","description":"<p>How do you access a Mac built in 1999 and last used in 2008 when you have no compatible display and barely any ports in common?</p>\n<p>No, this isn’t a riddle.</p>\n<p>Well, I guess, it’s <em>sort of</em> a riddle.</p>\n<p>Like many of you, I’ve been trying to find ways to keep occupied while stuck indoors, and after I’d done the dishes, put in some laundry, and got tired of reading the news, I turned to a long-procrastinated task: cleaning out all my electronics junk. This had a couple of phases, <a href=\"https://twitter.com/dmoren/status/1239585531077496834?s=20\">one of which was physical</a>, but the more time-consuming part has been mostly virtual, as I’ve been cleaning off computers and hard drives spanning back a couple decades.</p>\n<p>But I left the greatest challenge for last.</p>\n<blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\">\n<p lang=\"en\" dir=\"ltr\">Only one old computer left in the office. Time to see if this big boy boots. <a href=\"https://t.co/lUNHc66nbR\">pic.twitter.com/lUNHc66nbR</a></p>\n<p>— Dan Moren (@dmoren) <a href=\"https://twitter.com/dmoren/status/1242428353531052035?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">March 24, 2020</a></p></blockquote>\n<p><script async src=\"https://platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"></script></p>\n<p>My Blue &#38; White Power Mac G3. I unabashedly love this computer. While it wasn’t my first Mac, it was the first Mac that was truly <em>mine</em>. Acquired for my sophomore year of college, it was one of the first Macs to have a DVD drive (turning my dorm room into the place we watched movies on a laughably small 17-inch monitor), and it not only spanned the Classic Mac OS and Mac OS X eras, but saw numerous upgrades along the way, including an additional internal hard drive, the addition of a PCI card with four USB 2.0 ports, a RAM upgrade to a then-<em>amazing</em> 512MB, and even an eventual processor bump wherein a 600MHz G4 chip replaced the stock 400MHz G3.</p>\n<p>Basically, it’s been through a lot.</p>\n<h2>Make sure we’re connected</h2>\n<p>So, how to connect to this venerable machine? It has USB ports, FireWire 400 ports, and even an ADB port <em>and</em> a modem<sup id=\"fnref-10845-luxury\"><a href=\"https://sixcolors.com#fn-10845-luxury\" class=\"jetpack-footnote\">1</a></sup>, but it predates both FireWire’s Target Disk Mode (even if I had a machine with a FireWire port <em>or</em> the right combination of adapters to connect to it) and built-in wireless networking. I can’t even connect it to a monitor, as it only sports a VGA port, and I don’t have the means to connect that to either my HDTV or the old Apple Cinema Display I have in my office.</p>\n<p>Look, let’s cut to the chase: if all I wanted was to get old data off the machine, the easiest thing by far would be to pull the internal hard drives and pop them in <a href=\"https://twitter.com/dmoren/status/1240707308105023489\">a USB adapter</a>. Done and dusted.</p>\n<p>But I have to admit, I was curious: I wanted to see if the machine would boot and, moreover, if I could actually log in to it. I’d previously had good luck getting into my old Core Duo Mac mini by using an Ethernet cable<sup id=\"fnref-10845-crossover\"><a href=\"https://sixcolors.com#fn-10845-crossover\" class=\"jetpack-footnote\">2</a></sup> and logging in via <code>ssh</code>.  That took a little doing, but I figured what I’d learned from that exploit ought to prepare me well for this undertaking.</p>\n<p>Not even close.</p>\n<p>Both the G3 and the Mac mini started with a similar problem: I’d configured them to use static IP addresses. Ironically, this was accidentally complicated by the fact that I’d very recently replaced my ancient AirPort Extreme with an Eero base station—and, as it turns out, they use different subnets by default.<sup id=\"fnref-10845-subnets\"><a href=\"https://sixcolors.com#fn-10845-subnets\" class=\"jetpack-footnote\">3</a></sup></p>\n<p>My bacon was, fortunately, saved by two lucky breaks. Firstly, Apple’s Bonjour service<sup id=\"fnref-10845-rendezvous\"><a href=\"https://sixcolors.com#fn-10845-rendezvous\" class=\"jetpack-footnote\">4</a></sup>, which provides plain-English addresses and makes network discovery easier. Secondly, even though I could not originally get access by <code>ssh</code>ing into the static address (which I did not initially remember), the Bonjour name helpfully sent me to the G3’s IPv6 address, which <em>did</em> work.</p>\n<p>At first, that provided very little traction—scanning the ports with the <code>nmap</code> utility that I installed via <a href=\"https://brew.sh\">homebrew</a>, it seemed as though all the network ports on the G3 were blocked, even though I knew I’d frequently used <code>ssh</code> to log in to the machine remotely back in the day. Attempts to log in via screen sharing and file sharing were likewise fruitless. On a whim, I restarted the machine from the command line, at which point i was able to at least get a response on the <code>ssh</code> port, though still only via the IPv6 address.</p>\n<p>Then I hit the next roadblock: remembering the password of a machine that had not been booted for over a decade.</p>\n<h2>Too many secrets</h2>\n<p>Here’s where my guilty confession comes in. While I’ve mostly transitioned to using strong unique passwords for everything, my Mac login passwords have long been based on a certain predictable (to me) pattern. So while I didn’t remember the exact iteration of the password, I knew enough that in theory I ought to be able to reverse engineer it.</p>\n<p>I recruited friend of the site James Thomson to help and he quickly generated a list of 250 or so possible permutations based on an obfuscated pattern that I gave him. I planned to run those as a brute force attack over <code>ssh</code> using <a href=\"https://null-byte.wonderhowto.com/how-to/gain-ssh-access-servers-by-brute-forcing-credentials-0194263/\">some commonly available command line tools</a>.<sup id=\"fnref-10845-mrrobot\"><a href=\"https://sixcolors.com#fn-10845-mrrobot\" class=\"jetpack-footnote\">5</a></sup></p>\n<p>Alas, that attempt to get my Crash Override on was stymied by the fact that I could still only access the machine via its IPv6 address, which apparently doesn’t play nicely with macOS as far as those brute force tools are concerned. So, instead, I fired up Numbers and set about figuring out the most likely password candidates; I ended up with 48 possibilities.</p>\n<p>I hit the jackpot on number nine.</p>\n<blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\" data-conversation=\"none\">\n<p lang=\"en\" dir=\"ltr\">When I finally got in, the last login date on this computer was listed as Wednesday, January 23, 2008, or exactly 4444 days ago. ðŸ˜±(Also, my Cowboy Bebop nerdery is on full display with this machine.) <a href=\"https://t.co/A7pt6fWjhB\">pic.twitter.com/A7pt6fWjhB</a></p>\n<p>— Dan Moren (@dmoren) <a href=\"https://twitter.com/dmoren/status/1242492935511425025?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">March 24, 2020</a></p></blockquote>\n<p><script async src=\"https://platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"></script></p>\n<p>Upon login, I was not only greeted with a good old Terminal Message of the Day I’d put in some decades past, but also with the note that the last login had been on January 23, 2008, or—amazingly—exactly 4444 days ago.<sup id=\"fnref-10845-4444\"><a href=\"https://sixcolors.com#fn-10845-4444\" class=\"jetpack-footnote\">6</a></sup></p>\n<p>Once logged in via the command line, I figured the world was my oyster. I was able to use the terminal to <a href=\"https://osxdaily.com/2015/07/30/release-renew-dhcp-command-line-ipconfig/\">switch from the static IP address to DHCP</a>, so it could actually get on the network, and also use file sharing via the Finder so I could access all the (incredibly intact!) data on the machine.</p>\n<h2>Seeing is believing</h2>\n<p>I could have stopped there, but curiosity had gotten the better of me—I wanted to actually <em>see</em> this vintage machine in action. Seemed like I ought to be able to get screen sharing working; all it takes to enable it via the command line is <a href=\"https://support.apple.com/en-us/HT201710\">a literal kickstart</a>.</p>\n<p>Except this machine was running Mac OS X Panther 10.3.9…a version that <em>predated</em> the OS’s built-in screen sharing features.<sup id=\"fnref-10845-ard\"><a href=\"https://sixcolors.com#fn-10845-ard\" class=\"jetpack-footnote\">7</a></sup></p>\n<p>Whoops.</p>\n<p>Fortunately, past me was an even bigger nerd than present me, if such a thing is possible. I had a vague memory of using a third-party VNC server before screen-sharing was eventually built into the OS. So I checked the Applications folder and, sure enough, discovered the OSXvnc server app (now <a href=\"https://sourceforge.net/p/osxvnc/wiki/Home/\">Vine</a>). Digging into the app package via the command line, I was pretty sure that I should be able to start it with the right terminal command, and a little googling turned up a result from, of course, <a href=\"http://hints.macworld.com/article.php?story=20011206171635606\">Mac OS X Hints</a>, the site founded by my old Macworld colleague Rob Griffiths.</p>\n<p>With a little further googling about how to set the VNC server’s password, I got the service up and running, hit Connect to Server in the finder on my iMac and…<em>success</em>:</p>\n<figure><img src=\"https://i2.wp.com/sixcolors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/g3-macosx-panther-6c.jpg?ssl=1\" alt=\"Mac OS X Panther\" data-image-w=\"\" data-image-h=\"\" class=\" jetpack-broken-image\" data-recalc-dims=\"1\"><figcaption></figcaption></figure><p>Now this is a blast from the past. The finest software that 2005 has to offer. Enjoy the lickable Aqua interface! The brushed metal! The hacked dock that I pinned to the bottom right! There’s a copy of <a href=\"https://sixcolors.com/post/2016/11/achieving-escape-velocity-on-macos-sierra/\">EV Nova</a> and it probably even runs! It even still has the Classic environment for running old Mac OS applications.</p>\n<p>I’ve recovered the few files off this device that I didn’t have on other devices<sup id=\"fnref-10845-parody\"><a href=\"https://sixcolors.com#fn-10845-parody\" class=\"jetpack-footnote\">8</a></sup>, but I don’t have any plans to wipe this computer. As Nick Statt <a href=\"https://www.theverge.com/2020/4/1/21203294/amazon-prime-video-ios-in-app-purchases-iphone-ipad-apple-tv-change\">reports for the Verge</a>:</p>\n<blockquote><p>\n  Amazon’s Prime Video iOS and Apple TV apps now let customers make in-app purchases, including renting and buying films and TV shows… Prior to the change, Amazon would not allow you to rent or buy content on the Prime Video app, instead, directing users to a web browser.\n</p></blockquote>\n<p>I think Statt is conflating two different Apple policies, however. Up to now, the rule has been that if you sell digital goods within an app, you need to sell it using Apple’s own purchasing engine. And yes, the standard rate for in-app purchases using that system is 30 percent.</p>\n<p>But this doesn’t seem to be that. This is using Amazon’s own purchasing engine, the same one you’d run into if you switched out to Safari and rented or bought a movie there. I entered my Amazon security PIN and was allowed to rent “Jojo Rabbit” directly from Amazon using my linked payment method there, and received an Amazon receipt in email. Apple wasn’t involved in any way.</p>\n<p>I doubt that Amazon just went rogue, so clearly something has happened. Perhaps Amazon has agreed to cut Apple in for a percentage of total sales originating from the app. Or perhaps Apple dropped the whole thing. I don’t know. I look forward to the behind-the-scenes dirt emerging sometime.</p>\n<p>I checked out Amazon’s other digital-media apps, Kindle and <a href=\"https://sixcolors.com/post/2015/06/comixology-37-new-app-makes-the-best-of-the-amazonapple-situation/\">Comixology</a>, as well as the Amazon.com app, to see if I could buy digital goods directly from any of them. As of this writing, I couldn’t—but I wouldn’t be surprised if those apps are also about to get a sudden update that allows their users to buy digital goods directly rather than having to exit to a web browser to do so.</p>\n<p><strong>Update</strong>: Benjamin Mayo of 9to5Mac reports that if you don’t have a linked Amazon account, <a href=\"https://twitter.com/bzamayo/status/1245450778137034752\">the transaction uses Apple’s in-app purchase system</a>. It has fed a bunch of overhyped headlines around the web about malware on the Mac growing rapidly. What it really reveals is that the Mac is increasingly a target for annoying adware apps—which isn’t quite the same as malware. Meanwhile, Apple has also been adjusting its policies and adding new features to fight the spread of this stuff.</p>\n<p>Malwarebytes reports:</p>\n<blockquote><p>\n  …most Mac threats, and certainly the most prevalent ones of 2019, are families of adware and potentially unwanted programs (PUPs). The most common Mac malware family, OSX.Generic. Suspicious, fell well down the list at 30th place in Mac- specific detections, and hundreds of spots down on a cross-platform threat list.\n</p></blockquote>\n<p>The key here is to differentiate between adware, PUPs, and malware. The top 29 bad actors tracked by Malwarebytes in 2019 were adware or PUPs, which are annoying and disingenuous but not considered actually harmful. The big new entry in 2019 was called <a href=\"https://forums.malwarebytes.com/topic/164444-removal-instructions-for-taplika-new-tab/\">New Tab</a> and is a browser hijacker.</p>\n<p><span id=\"more-4106\"></span></p>\n<p>It’s worth considering the tools Apple has at its disposal to make the Mac safe from questionable software. First, there’s the Mac App Store, which has a rigorous approval process that blocks most or all of the techniques that these sorts of apps use. Occasionally something leaks through, but those mistakes are rare and rapidly corrected. If you’re only downloading software from the Mac App Store, you’re pretty much safe.</p>\n<p>Next is Apple’s relatively new <a href=\"https://sixcolors.com/post/2018/06/with-mojave-apple-makes-changes-inside-and-outside-mac-app-store/\">notarization</a> process. Sofware developers now have to pass their apps through an automated analysis on an Apple server, and then Apple cryptographically signs the app. Apps that fail some checks can be rejected, and Apple can remotely kill those apps if they are found to be behaving badly.</p>\n<p>And then there’s Gatekeeper, which scans apps when you launch them and doesn’t let them run unless they pass a bunch of checks. Depending on your Mac’s security settings, Gatekeeper can prevent the launching of software that doesn’t pass muster.</p>\n<p>The Malwarebytes report covers the entirety of calendar year 2019, but in November Apple actually stepped up its efforts to identify problematic software and clarified some of its policies to give it wider latitude to shut off software that doesn’t quite fit the definition of malware. Apple pointed me to <a href=\"https://developer.apple.com/support/protecting-users-from-suspicious-software/\">this note to developers</a> that specifies what kinds of software will be considered for removal. There are three kinds:</p>\n<ul><li><strong>Deceptive apps</strong> that misrepresent functionality, mimic other software, make misleading claims, or consume resources without user content.</li>\n<li><strong>Difficult to remove apps</strong> that fight to stay on your Mac, want to charge you a fee to remove themselves, or display ads outside the app.</li>\n<li><strong>Apps that degrade security or privacy</strong> and are therefore more classic definitions of malware. This category also includes apps that violate a user’s privacy expectations by transmitting sensitive data elsewhere that is contrary to the stated purpose of the software.</li>\n</ul><p>Now, does this mean that Apple is going to shut down all of those apps that claim to clean your system and keep it running smoothly? Though most Mac experts would suggest that such apps are not really necessary, it’s an arguable point—and Apple appears to be erring on the side of allowing apps in that gray area to exist. At least, so long as they don’t violate other aspects of its policies. (The FDA doesn’t prohibit homeopathic remedies, either.)</p>\n<p>It seems that many of the items in Malwarebytes’ report have gotten the hammer from Apple and are no longer actively circulating. The report’s long list of Mac software is an alert that the Mac is now a much more enticing target for makers of adware and other scam software. It certainly can’t be a coincidence that Apple is stepping up enforcement of its policies at the same time that the number of these sleazy apps is increasing.</p>\n<p>There is also one very interesting observation in the Malwarebytes report that gives me pause, as someone who uses the Mac’s unix underpinnings to drive a lot of automation:</p>\n<blockquote><p>\n  We expect to see that trend continue in 2020 as Apple tightens the requirements and conditions for checking, code signing, and notarization. Since shell scripts are exempt from these restrictions, we expect to see them used more and more by malware.\n</p></blockquote>\n<p>I would imagine that future versions of macOS will make it harder to run arbitrary shell scripts, which is a bummer—but if that’s where the scoundrels are heading, Apple’s security team will have to chase them there. This is why we can’t have nice things.</p>\n<p>As the creators of anti-malware software, Malwarebytes is perfectly positioned to understand these trends, and their report is full of valuable information. At the same time, their business also potentially benefits if Mac users are more fearful about malware. And Malwarebytes’s Mac expert, Thomas Reed, stoked those fears <a href=\"https://www.vox.com/recode/2020/2/12/21134681/mac-pc-virus-malware-malwarebytes\">in an interview with Recode</a>:</p>\n<blockquote><p>\n  There is a rising tide of Mac threats hitting a population that still believes that ‘Macs don’t get viruses,'” Reed said. “I still frequently encounter people who firmly believe this, and who believe that using any kind of security software is not necessary, or even harmful. This makes macOS a fertile ground for the influx of new threats, whereas it’s common knowledge that Windows PCs need security software.”\n</p></blockquote>\n<p>It’s valid to wonder if the Mac’s reputation for being a safe harbor leads some Mac users to make bad security choices. But “Macs don’t get viruses” is a statement that is still overwhelmingly true. Even if it makes it awfully hard to sell Mac anti-malware software.</p>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Thu, 13 Feb 2020 16:11:48 +0000","feedId":1506,"bgimg":"https://i1.wp.com/sixcolors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/malwarebytes2019.jpg?ssl=1","linkMd5":"6734e23d1a96cbf5311b88b54ef524fa","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn67@2020_3/2020/08/24/18-19-10-024_d4d8495c918c4d43.webp","destWidth":1360,"destHeight":888,"sourceBytes":46228,"destBytes":46228,"author":"Jason Snell","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i1.wp.com/sixcolors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/malwarebytes2019.jpg?ssl=1":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn67@2020_3/2020/08/24/18-19-10-024_d4d8495c918c4d43.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598293144629},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 02:19:04","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 02:19:04","title":"(Sponsor) SoundSource","link":"http://two.wordpress.test/post/2020/03/feed_sponsor_soundsource/","description":"<p>My thanks once again to Rogue Amoeba and <a href=\"https://rogueamoeba.com/sentBy.php?6CSS2\">SoundSource</a> for sponsoring Six Colors this week. It’s like a little cartoon character, the plucky dot who is up to any challenge, even if it means contorting itself into whatever form is required.</p>\n<p>Consider the animation when it enters and exits an existing button. The circle oozes out into a curved rectangle, like it’s some sort of sticky blob. When it’s over the active area, the whole button tilts as if the blob is pulling it around. Move far enough, though, and the blob breaks back off of the button and returns to its traditional shape as a simple circle.</p>\n<figure class=\"pull-right\"><img src=\"https://i2.wp.com/sixcolors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/dot-to-i-beam.gif?ssl=1\" data-image-w=\"\" data-image-h=\"\" class=\" jetpack-broken-image\" data-recalc-dims=\"1\"></figure><p>Then there’s the transition from the standard cursor to the text-editing version. On the Mac, this is an instant conversion—one moment you’re seeing an arrow, the next you’re seeing the I-beam text editing cursor.</p>\n<p>In contrast, on iPadOS 13.4 the dot squashes, getting taller and thinner until it transforms into an editing cursor. This is completely unnecessary animation, but it’s delightful, and I’m impressed that Apple went to the trouble to create it.</p>\n<p>The iOS text-editing cursor is a simple, unadorned sliver with curved corners. Just as the circle is much simpler than the traditional macOS arrow, this sliver is all soft and round while the Mac’s I-beam cursor is all sharp edges—not just at top and bottom, but right in the middle, too. You could put an eye out with that thing.</p>\n<p>(Developers <a href=\"https://twitter.com/wooji/status/1242851479955943426\">will be able to add their own custom cursors</a> as well, and I’m looking forward to seeing how that plays out.)</p>\n<p>Finally, I wanted to praise the subtle way that Apple deals with making the cursor visible no matter what it’s hovering over.</p>\n<figure class=\"pull-right\"><img src=\"https://i2.wp.com/sixcolors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/dot-reverse.gif?ssl=1\" data-image-w=\"\" data-image-h=\"\" class=\" jetpack-broken-image\" data-recalc-dims=\"1\"></figure><p>On the Mac, the arrow cursor is black with a thick white outline, so it’ll be equally visible on dark and light backgrounds. On the iPad, it’s a gray circle—but one that’s intelligent about what colors surround it. When it’s over a white background, it’s dark gray—but move it over a dark area, and it will brighten into a light gray. Move it back over a light background, and it deepens back to dark gray.</p>\n<p>Apple didn’t just copy Mac cursor support and paste it into iPadOS with version 13.4. This is a careful, considered set of additions that rethink what a cursor should look like. And apparently it should look like an adorable round sticky color-changing blob.</p>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Tue, 24 Mar 2020 23:30:00 +0000","feedId":1506,"bgimg":"https://i1.wp.com/sixcolors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/hidden-button.gif?ssl=1","linkMd5":"99a5fb3b6a7f78cc5df8a663769f3458","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn96@2020_1/2020/08/24/18-19-09-727_87a7bb52b80517ab.webp","destWidth":194,"destHeight":126,"sourceBytes":140058,"destBytes":65692,"author":"Jason Snell","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i1.wp.com/sixcolors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/hidden-button.gif?ssl=1":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn96@2020_1/2020/08/24/18-19-09-727_87a7bb52b80517ab.webp","https://i2.wp.com/sixcolors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/dot-to-i-beam.gif?ssl=1":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn84@2020_4/2020/08/24/18-19-17-596_7aefc29876c7a582.webp","https://i2.wp.com/sixcolors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/dot-reverse.gif?ssl=1":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn44@2020_1/2020/08/24/18-19-14-653_2f5c9ea091ae3906.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598293144589},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 02:19:04","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 02:19:04","title":"Quick Tip: Customize your Terminal login with a message of the day","link":"http://two.wordpress.test/post/2020/03/quick_tip_customize_your_terminal_login_with_a_message_of_the_day/","description":"<p>My <a href=\"https://sixcolors.com/post/2020/03/unpacking-hacking-and-cracking-a-powermac-g3/\">adventure resurrecting my Power Mac G3</a> not only brought to light old files, but also some old computing habits, prompting a question from one Twitter user:</p>\n<blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\">\n<p lang=\"en\" dir=\"ltr\">I appreciate the subtle Cowboy Bebop reference in that terminal sceeenshot ðŸ˜…</p>\n<p>Is that still a thing in macOS/Unix? Custom launch messages in terminal?</p>\n<p>— Jason<img src=\"https://s.w.org/images/core/emoji/13.0.0/72x72/2122.png\" alt=\"™\" class=\"wp-smiley\" style=\"height: 1em; max-height: 1em;\" /> @ SÌ¶aÌ¶kÌ¶uÌ¶rÌ¶aÌ¶-Ì¶CÌ¶oÌ¶nÌ¶ ðŸ˜ž (@yuusharo) <a href=\"https://twitter.com/yuusharo/status/1242518988925440000?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">March 24, 2020</a></p></blockquote>\n<p><script async src=\"https://platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"></script></p>\n<p>That custom logon message—aka the Message of the Day or MOTD—was once a staple of the command line, and yes, it <em>is</em> still a thing, even in the most recent version of macOS. Customizing it is simple.</p>\n<p>Just pop open a Terminal window, and open the <code>/etc/motd</code> file in your favorite text editor. I prefer <code>nano</code><sup id=\"fnref-10850-viemacs\"><a href=\"https://sixcolors.com#fn-10850-viemacs\" class=\"jetpack-footnote\">1</a></sup> so, I would just run this command:</p>\n<p><code>sudo nano /etc/motd</code></p>\n<figure><img src=\"https://i2.wp.com/sixcolors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/terminal-motd-6c.jpg?ssl=1\" alt=\"Editing the MOTD\" data-image-w=\"\" data-image-h=\"\" class=\" jetpack-broken-image\" data-recalc-dims=\"1\"><figcaption></figcaption></figure><p>Once you enter your administrator password, you’ll get a blank text edit window into which you can enter a message. Save that file (in <code>nano</code>, type ctrl-x and then ‘y’ when prompted to save) and the next time you open a new Terminal window, you’ll be greeted with your message of the day. Make sure to make it something upbeat—we all need it these days.</p>\n<div class=\"footnotes\">\n<hr><ol><li id=\"fn-10850-viemacs\">\nNano: the only way to stay out of the vi vs. emacs turf war. <a href=\"https://sixcolors.com#fnref-10850-viemacs\"><img src=\"https://s.w.org/images/core/emoji/13.0.0/72x72/21a9.png\" alt=\"↩\" class=\"wp-smiley\" style=\"height: 1em; max-height: 1em;\" /></a>\n</li>\n</ol></div>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Thu, 26 Mar 2020 13:30:12 +0000","feedId":1506,"bgimg":"https://s.w.org/images/core/emoji/13.0.0/72x72/2122.png","linkMd5":"bd0cd60fba6da1f0a44c9c5f5775e12b","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn7@2020_1/2020/08/24/18-19-08-087_03be5e4393e715e0.webp","destWidth":72,"destHeight":72,"sourceBytes":613,"destBytes":1242,"author":"Dan Moren","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://s.w.org/images/core/emoji/13.0.0/72x72/2122.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn7@2020_1/2020/08/24/18-19-08-087_03be5e4393e715e0.webp","https://i2.wp.com/sixcolors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/terminal-motd-6c.jpg?ssl=1":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn60@2020_6/2020/08/24/18-19-16-335_26fa6bd3e8bcf991.webp","https://s.w.org/images/core/emoji/13.0.0/72x72/21a9.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn51@2020_2/2020/08/24/18-19-11-215_25686225908fe44d.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598293144659},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 02:19:04","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 02:19:04","title":"Clever, Powerful, Useful: Time to upgrade the Mac’s energy settings","link":"http://two.wordpress.test/post/2020/01/clever_powerful_useful_time_to_upgrade_the_macs_energy_settings/","description":"<p>Back in the olden days of the early 1990s, the Mac’s built-in power-management software was not great. Third-party apps filled the gap, the most impressive of which was <a href=\"https://tidbits.com/1992/08/10/cpu/\">Connectix PowerBook Utilities</a> (CPU). As Adam Engst wrote 28 years ago(!):</p>\n<blockquote><p>\n  CPU’s most important features are its power saving features, and these abound. First, you can easily configure the times to spin down the hard drive, rest the processor, dim the backlighting, and put the PowerBook to sleep. Second, you can activate any of these power-saving measures with a hot-key, so I often shut down the hard drive when it wasn’t doing anything because I enjoy working on a silent PowerBook… Finally, Connectix recognized that you use the PowerBook in different places, so you can create sets of settings.\n</p></blockquote>\n<figure class=\"pull-right\"><img src=\"https://i0.wp.com/sixcolors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/cpu-computinghistory-6c.jpg?ssl=1\" alt=\"cpu-computinghistory\" data-image-w=\"\" data-image-h=\"\" class=\" jetpack-broken-image\" data-recalc-dims=\"1\"><figcaption>(<a href=\"http://www.computinghistory.org.uk/det/48427/Connectix-PowerBook-Utilities/\">Centre for Computing History</a>)</figcaption></figure><p>A lot of these features ended up in Mac OS, as they rightly should have, and CPU faded into oblivion. But I’ve been thinking about CPU a lot this week, after the 9to5Mac report that <a href=\"https://ww.9to5mac.com/2020/01/13/macos-beta-hints-at-future-pro-mode-to-boost-performance-on-portable-macs/\">a “Pro Mode” may be coming to a future version of macOS</a>. It seems to be a new setting that would decrease laptop battery life and increase fan noise in order to perform processor-intensive operations.</p>\n<p>Fair enough. But as <a href=\"https://marco.org/2020/01/13/macos-low-power-mode-redux\">Marco Arment</a> and <a href=\"https://ww.9to5mac.com/2020/01/13/macos-low-power-mode/#\">Chance Miller</a> pointed out last week, this feature seems to have missed the bigger opportunity on the other side of the coin: an iOS-style “Low-Power Mode” that would let MacBook users eke out longer battery life by tweaking settings, including disabling Turbo Boost on processors. A utility, <a href=\"https://www.rugarciap.com/turbo-boost-switcher-for-os-x/\">Turbo Boost Switcher</a> by Rugar Ciap (free; the pro version is $9), does this job—but throws up a warning suggesting that it might not be allowed to work with the next major version of macOS.</p>\n<p>I’m all for the idea of a low-power mode for Macs<sup id=\"fnref-4065-ipad\"><a href=\"https://sixcolors.com#fn-4065-ipad\" class=\"jetpack-footnote\">1</a></sup>, and it’s a bit perplexing to see Apple prioritize turning off all battery-saving features and cranking the fans over letting users maximize battery life.</p>\n<p>I do have a wacky idea, though. (You knew I would.) What if Apple used the introduction of Pro Mode to adjust the <em>default</em> performance settings of macOS laptops? Yes, raw benchmark scores would drop, but in exchange Apple could make more expansive battery-life claims. Users who demand the best performance from their pro laptops could enable Pro Mode, which would drain that battery quickly, but in general use the laptops would run cooler and quieter and last longer. What if the way Marco uses his MacBook Pro—with Turbo Bost Switcher turned on—were the default for everyone?</p>\n<p>Of course, a better idea would be to provide users with more granular power-management controls, perhaps even with location-aware presets like Connectix PowerBook Utilities offered in the early 90s. I know that Apple’s tendency is to prevent users from fiddling with their computers’ settings in detail, but let’s be honest—the Energy Saver system preference pane is already an enormous collection of sliders and checkboxes. Adding a few more wouldn’t hurt anyone.</p>\n<figure><img src=\"https://i0.wp.com/sixcolors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/energy-util-6c.jpg?ssl=1\" alt=\"\" data-image-w=\"\" data-image-h=\"\" class=\" jetpack-broken-image\" data-recalc-dims=\"1\"><figcaption>It’s not like this isn’t already a complex spot.</figcaption></figure><p>While we’re at it, can we finally add a Low Data Mode to macOS as well? For years I’ve extolled the virtues of <a href=\"https://www.tripmode.ch\">TripMode</a>, an $8 utility that lets you control what Mac apps have access to the Internet if you’re using a slow or metered connection. That’s a feature that should just be built into macOS, though perhaps not with the level of granularity that TripMode offers. (It’s a classic Mac approach to build a new feature with a very simple set of user options, and then allow third parties to offer more complex interfaces on top of that same feature for the users who really care—so the introduction of a Low Data Mode need not be the end of powerful apps like TripMode.)</p>\n<p>Offering macOS apps better control over data usage would also perhaps open the door for cellular-equipped Mac laptops a bit wider. I’ve been using a cellular iPad Pro for the last few years, and I would never go back. The convenience of not having to tether to a phone or worry about the quality of the local Wi-Fi is worth the extra cost, and it’s a shame that MacBook users don’t have the chance to make that choice.</p>\n<div class=\"footnotes\">\n<hr><ol><li id=\"fn-4065-ipad\">\nI’d like one for iPads, too. <a href=\"https://sixcolors.com#fnref-4065-ipad\"><img src=\"https://s.w.org/images/core/emoji/13.0.0/72x72/21a9.png\" alt=\"↩\" class=\"wp-smiley\" style=\"height: 1em; max-height: 1em;\" /></a>\n</li>\n</ol></div>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 17 Jan 2020 10:57:00 +0000","feedId":1506,"bgimg":"https://i0.wp.com/sixcolors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/cpu-computinghistory-6c.jpg?ssl=1","linkMd5":"1a2d55ff42e140783ce391fc1cf7c16e","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn96@2020_3/2020/08/24/18-19-06-586_c57ab0519683c89c.webp","destWidth":680,"destHeight":1012,"sourceBytes":88446,"destBytes":88446,"author":"Jason Snell","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i0.wp.com/sixcolors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/cpu-computinghistory-6c.jpg?ssl=1":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn96@2020_3/2020/08/24/18-19-06-586_c57ab0519683c89c.webp","https://i0.wp.com/sixcolors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/energy-util-6c.jpg?ssl=1":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn67@2020_2/2020/08/24/18-19-13-750_fdcf6a73dcd27124.webp","https://s.w.org/images/core/emoji/13.0.0/72x72/21a9.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn51@2020_2/2020/08/24/18-19-11-215_25686225908fe44d.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598293144652},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 02:19:04","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 02:19:04","title":"Fun With Charts: Time for a change?","link":"http://two.wordpress.test/post/2020/05/fun_with_charts_time_for_a_change/","description":"<p>For this week’s chart<sup id=\"fnref-10963-technically\"><a href=\"https://sixcolors.com#fn-10963-technically\" class=\"jetpack-footnote\">1</a></sup>, I thought I’d illustrate how long Apple has historically stuck with different processor architectures. As you probably know, there are lots of reports that in the next year, Apple will begin to roll out Macs powered by its own ARM processors rather than those made by Intel. (Dan and I actually discussed it in depth on this week’s Six Colors podcast, which is available to all <a href=\"https://sixcolors.com/subscribe/\">Six Colors subscribers</a>.)</p>\n<figure><img src=\"https://i2.wp.com/sixcolors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/marchoftime-version-5-6c.png?ssl=1\" alt=\"\" data-image-w=\"\" data-image-h=\"\" class=\" jetpack-broken-image\" data-recalc-dims=\"1\"><figcaption></figcaption></figure><p>This wouldn’t be the Mac’s first processor transition. It’s already been through two, and I’ve been privileged to witness them both. The Motorola 68000 era lasted for the Mac’s first 12 years (non-PowerPC PowerBooks… lingered). In 1994, the PowerPC transition began, and Apple shipped Macs with PowerPC processors for 12 years.</p>\n<p>At 14 years and counting, the Intel era is the longest in the Mac’s history. The transition was also the fastest—Apple really cleared out the PowerPC Macs in a hurry and replaced them with Intel models.</p>\n<p>While it’s theoretically possible that Apple could swap every Mac model to ARM processors in 2021, it seems unlikely. You’ll probably be able to buy a new Mac running Intel chips into 2022, and possibly for many years after that. But it seems that change is coming (again) to the Mac.</p>\n<div class=\"footnotes\">\n<hr><ol><li id=\"fn-10963-technically\">\nTechnically, I already made a chart this week—<a href=\"https://sixcolors.com/post/2020/05/bad-shortcuts-ripping-data-out-of-a-webpage-to-make-a-chart/\">and built it via a Shortcut</a>. <a href=\"https://sixcolors.com#fnref-10963-technically\"><img src=\"https://s.w.org/images/core/emoji/13.0.0/72x72/21a9.png\" alt=\"↩\" class=\"wp-smiley\" style=\"height: 1em; max-height: 1em;\" /></a>\n</li>\n</ol></div>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 15 May 2020 20:16:18 +0000","feedId":1506,"bgimg":"https://i2.wp.com/sixcolors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/marchoftime-version-5-6c.png?ssl=1","linkMd5":"600546cf245a34b2d3acc89acdf7a88f","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn63@2020_1/2020/08/24/18-19-09-222_d93a828b25ee14a8.webp","destWidth":1360,"destHeight":397,"sourceBytes":17996,"destBytes":17996,"author":"Jason Snell","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i2.wp.com/sixcolors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/marchoftime-version-5-6c.png?ssl=1":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn63@2020_1/2020/08/24/18-19-09-222_d93a828b25ee14a8.webp","https://s.w.org/images/core/emoji/13.0.0/72x72/21a9.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn51@2020_2/2020/08/24/18-19-11-215_25686225908fe44d.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598293144244},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 02:19:04","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 02:19:04","title":"From cover to cover: Adventures in self-publishing","link":"http://two.wordpress.test/post/2020/05/from_cover_to_cover_adventures_in_self-publishing/","description":"<figure><img src=\"https://i2.wp.com/sixcolors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/selfpub-applebooks-6c.jpg?ssl=1\" alt=\"\" data-image-w=\"\" data-image-h=\"\" class=\" jetpack-broken-image\" data-recalc-dims=\"1\"><figcaption></figcaption></figure><p>Back in the mid-’90s, my friend Jason<sup id=\"fnref-10929-norelation\"><a href=\"https://sixcolors.com#fn-10929-norelation\" class=\"jetpack-footnote\">1</a></sup> and I started up an online magazine devoted to fantasy and science-fiction. We originally set out distributing it on local bulletin boards as a self-contained app generated by a program called <a href=\"http://www.mac.org/utilities/docmaker/\">DOCMaker</a>, but as the popularity of the web rose, we eventually transitioned there.</p>\n<p>For many years, that was the most experience I had with self-publishing, until a couple weeks ago, when I decided to embark upon a new experiment: <a href=\"https://dmoren.com/short-stories\">putting out ebook versions of a couple short stories</a> in the same Galactic Cold War universe as <a href=\"https://dmoren.com/writing/\">my three novels</a>.</p>\n<p>One of the things about being a traditionally published author is that your publisher takes care of the actual production of a book: you hand over a Word doc, they turn it into something that people will actually end up reading. As a result, this experiment meant that I needed to learn some new skills, and find some tools to help me along the way.</p>\n<h2>Duck and cover</h2>\n<p>Visual art has never been one of my strengths—there’s a reason I deal in words, friend. But whoever said that you shouldn’t judge a book by its cover has never dealt with the reality of sales: one of my former agents was convinced that the only things that really sell books are the first line and the cover.</p>\n<p>So, if I was going to put out an ebook, it needed to have a good cover: not just some sort of slapped-on placeholder with the title and my name on it. Something eye-catching that also linked it into the visual identity of my series. The suggestion—from that same friend, Jason, who now has a sideline in creating independent tabletop RPGs—was to take advantage of some stock art.</p>\n<p>When we think of stock art, we probably think of things like cartoonish clip art or <a href=\"https://www.thehairpin.com/2011/01/women-laughing-alone-with-salad/\">ridiculous photos of women eating salad</a>. But that, folks, is your parents’ stock art: <a href=\"https://www.shutterstock.com/\">Shutterstock</a>, the vendor I went to, has a huge catalog of beautiful pieces of art by incredibly talented photographers and illustrators. So I bought an affordable 5-pack of licenses for $50, and picked out a couple of images that I thought evoked the feelings of the stories.</p>\n<p>Armed with illustrations far beyond my ability, I turned to my trusty image editor, Flying Meat’s <a href=\"https://flyingmeat.com/acorn/\">Acorn</a> to help transform them into book covers. While I’ve dabbled in Photoshop, I’ve never been particularly good at it—it’s simply too complex for most of the things I need to do. But I’ve been using Acorn for years<sup id=\"fnref-10929-gus\"><a href=\"https://sixcolors.com#fn-10929-gus\" class=\"jetpack-footnote\">2</a></sup>, ever since my early days at the MacUser blog, though mainly for trivial tasks like cropping and resizing. This was a step above.</p>\n<figure><img src=\"https://i2.wp.com/sixcolors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/selfpub-acorn-6c.jpg?ssl=1\" alt=\"Acorn\" data-image-w=\"\" data-image-h=\"\" class=\" jetpack-broken-image\" data-recalc-dims=\"1\"><figcaption>Acorn’s powerful Path Text feature lets you easily create text that follows a shape.</figcaption></figure><p>Mainly I wanted to spend some time crafting title and byline text that looked like the covers of my books and, after taking a very time-consuming approach for my first several attempts, I figured there must be an easier way to design styled text.</p>\n<p>That led me to Acorn’s impressive Path Text feature, which lets you simply draw a shape and have the text follow its edge. (Basic stuff for some, I’m sure, but for me it was an Archimedes-in-the-bathtub moment.) I pulled accent colors from the images to make the text pop, and then created some duplicate text for the shadow effect and voila! (Okay, that makes it sound quick, but it took me a few days and repeated stabs until I got something that looked right.)</p>\n<p>Despite my years of usage, I came away with a new appreciation for Acorn: for a $30 app, it is an incredibly powerful piece of software, and it puts out a great-looking book cover.</p>\n<h2>Book ’em, me-o</h2>\n<p>Of course, the cover is literally just the beginning. It’s what lies within that is the reason for this whole endeavor.</p>\n<p>The good news is that I’m no stranger to generating ebooks: when I send drafts to my beta readers, it’s generally in the ebook format of their choice.</p>\n<p>There are a few options in this arena. If you’re looking to make ebooks on the cheap, Apple’s own free <a href=\"https://www.apple.com/pages/\">Pages</a> can not only generate ePub files, but publish directly to Apple Books. On the other end of the spectrum, the $200 <a href=\"https://vellum.pub\">Vellum</a> lets you design and tweak to your heart’s content, and includes a handy preview mode.</p>\n<figure><img src=\"https://i0.wp.com/sixcolors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/selfpub-scrivener-6c.jpg?ssl=1\" alt=\"Scrivener\" data-image-w=\"\" data-image-h=\"\" class=\" jetpack-broken-image\" data-recalc-dims=\"1\"><figcaption>Scrivener’s novel template works well for creating an ebook.</figcaption></figure><p>At $50, Literature and Latte’s <a href=\"https://www.literatureandlatte.com/scrivener/overview\">Scrivener</a> falls in between the two. It’s not strictly for making ebooks—that’s merely a feature of the app, which I use for the whole process of writing the books themselves, but Scrivener’s robust export tools mean that I can generate everything from a DOC file to an ePub. Previously, it used to even make Kindle books with the help of a command line tool from Amazon, but that tool has been deprecated, as I discovered during my foray into production.</p>\n<p>I ended up using Scrivener’s built-in novel template, pasting in the text from the original documents in which I’d written it, and then customizing the various front/after matter sections, such as the “Also By” page, the about the author page, and the afterword that I wrote for each of the short stories. That template worked well, and required only minimal massaging in order to adapt it to a shorter form work.</p>\n<p>Good as Scrivener is, it took me several attempts to get everything formatted the way I wanted, which does illustrate one downside of the process: every time you make a change, no matter how minor, you have to export the file, open it in a reader app like Books, and then eventually, when you discover that, say, the indentation is off, delete it from Books and restart the whole process. Vellum’s fancy preview mode would certainly be a big help there.</p>\n<figure><img src=\"https://i1.wp.com/sixcolors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/selfpub-kindlepreviewer-6c.jpg?ssl=1\" alt=\"Kindle Previewer\" data-image-w=\"\" data-image-h=\"\" class=\" jetpack-broken-image\" data-recalc-dims=\"1\"><figcaption>Amazon’s Kindle Previewer lets you see how your book would look on one of the company’s e-readers, as well as convert formats.</figcaption></figure><p>I mentioned that Amazon’s command-line tool had been deprecated—it’s been replaced by a new app, <a href=\"https://www.amazon.com/gp/feature.html?ie=UTF8&#38;docId=1000765261\">Kindle Previewer</a>, that has some advantages over the old version. For one, rather than simply converting to Amazon’s MOBI (or newer KPF) format, it lets you open a file  (ePub, DOC, HTML, and more), and see how it would look on a Kindle. Think of it a bit like Xcode’s iOS simulator, but for Kindles. It’s handy, seeing as how the Kindle is a bit of black box and you want to make sure your file looks as good as it possible can without having to sideload it to a Kindle to check every single time.</p>\n<p>And just to check and make sure that the ePubs I generated were correct in every way, I ran them through <a href=\"https://github.com/w3c/epubcheck/\">epubcheck</a>, a free tool that validates the file structure. By default it’s a command line tool, though there are <a href=\"https://github.com/w3c/epubcheck/wiki/GUI\">several free GUI versions available as well</a>. I used the free <a href=\"https://www.pagina.gmbh/produkte/epub-checker/\">pagina EPUB-Checker</a>, which assured me that Scrivener’s ebook files were up to snuff.</p>\n<h2>The whole store-y</h2>\n<p>Ah, those blissful days of ignorance before I had to navigate self-publishing platforms. Turns out: there are a lot of them. I settled on using five of the most popular ebook platforms: Amazon, Apple Books, Barnes &#38; Noble, Kobo, and Google Play Books.</p>\n<p>The first problem is that submitting to each of these platforms individually is a pain. There are sites that aggregate much of this, perhaps most notably <a href=\"https://www.smashwords.com\">Smashwords</a>, but there  are some limitations to its approach. For one, it distributes the same ebook file to all of the platforms, so you’re out of luck if you want any differences between versions of your books—for example, store-specific links (i.e. you want the Apple Books version of your ebook to include links to Apple Books versions of <em>other</em> books). More to the point, Smashwords doesn’t include Amazon, and there’s no denying just how big Amazon is. (In <a href=\"https://dmoren.com/2020/04/17/how-are-those-free-ebooks-doing/\">my stats</a> for the first couple weeks of availability, it accounted for almost half of downloads.)</p>\n<p>So I ended up submitting directly to each site, which it had its upsides and downsides. One good point, to take away for the future: all of the stores support uploading ePubs, mostly because that’s the format that all but Amazon use to distribute books. Amazon will convert from ePub to its own proprietary format, but I used the aforementioned Kindle Previewer to do the conversion beforehand, to make sure everything looked right.</p>\n<p>Each platform has its idiosyncrasies, such as release dates. Some, such as Kobo, let you actually schedule the date your title will show up in the system. In most others, you can set the “on sale” date, but the books will show up in the system as soon as they propagate, which—in my case—let the cat out of the bag a bit early, as people stumbled across them.</p>\n<p>Amazon is the only one that doesn’t allow you to make your ebook free by default: it has to go for at least 99 cents in the U.S., and a commensurate price in other countries. However, you can submit price-matching requests with links from other platforms; the problem there is you have to do it separately for each individual country in which the book is available, which is a real pain.</p>\n<figure><img src=\"https://i1.wp.com/sixcolors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/selfpub-itunesproducer-6c.jpg?ssl=1\" alt=\"iTunes Producer\" data-image-w=\"\" data-image-h=\"\" class=\" jetpack-broken-image\" data-recalc-dims=\"1\"><figcaption>Uploading books to the Apple Bookstore requires using the iTunes Producer app.</figcaption></figure><p>And while Apple lets you manage your titles via a web-based version of iTunes Connect (similar to the system it uses for apps), it took me a while to figure out that actually <em>uploading</em> the book files themselves requires use of Apple’s <a href=\"https://itunespartner.apple.com/books/tools\">iTunes Producer</a> app or, as mentioned previously, Pages.</p>\n<p>Each platform also differs in terms of the stats they provide, with Amazon, Kobo, and Apple being the best of the batch. Barnes &#38; Noble, for some reason, delays its ebook sales numbers by two days, which is perplexing since one would assume it must have real time information about the transfer of bits <em>somewhere</em>. Google requires you to download a spreadsheet in order to see your downloads, which is just bizarre from a company so dedicated to analytics.</p>\n<p>In addition to all of those stores, of course, I also made the files available <a href=\"https://dmoren.com/short-stories\">on my blog</a><sup id=\"fnref-10929-statsupdate\"><a href=\"https://sixcolors.com#fn-10929-statsupdate\" class=\"jetpack-footnote\">3</a></sup>, though it wasn’t until a day or so after I put them up that I realized I had no way to track how many downloads were happening there. I eventually settled on the free version of Never5’s <a href=\"https://www.download-monitor.com\">Download Monitor</a> extension for WordPress, which does that and a whole lot more.</p>\n<h2>Teaching an old dog new tricks</h2>\n<p>I took a few things away from this whole experience. First up, hoo boy, am I glad I have a publisher to handle all of this. It is a <em>lot</em> of work, and most thankless back-breaking detail-oriented work, at that. I’ve got a whole new appreciation for both the professionals who do that job for publishers as well as authors who self-publish their work.</p>\n<p>Secondly—and perhaps even more importantly—I’ve learned that I <em>can</em> do this. It requires moving out of my comfort zone in terms of skills, and finding some new tools, but generally I found that if I forged ahead, I could usually figure out what I was trying to accomplish, albeit with a few missteps here and there. Who knows if I’ll self-publish any of my work in the future—but at least I know I have the option, and with a little hard work and attention to details, the end result can come out looking pretty great.</p>\n<p><em><strong>Updated on 5/1/2020</strong> to add a paragraph about epubcheck validation tools.</em></p>\n<div class=\"footnotes\">\n<hr><ol><li id=\"fn-10929-norelation\">\nNo relation. <a href=\"https://sixcolors.com#fnref-10929-norelation\"><img src=\"https://s.w.org/images/core/emoji/13.0.0/72x72/21a9.png\" alt=\"↩\" class=\"wp-smiley\" style=\"height: 1em; max-height: 1em;\" /></a>\n</li>\n<li id=\"fn-10929-gus\">\nIn the interests of disclosure, Acorn developer Gus Mueller is a friend whom I’ve also known for years. +0000","feedId":1506,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"26845a6362c7a564e95768d68fd40f13","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"Jason Snell","publishedOrCreatedDate":1598293144225},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 02:19:04","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 02:19:04","title":"Put anything in your Mac’s menu bar with BitBar","link":"https://sixcolors.com/?p=12940","description":"<figure><img src=\"https://i0.wp.com/sixcolors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/bitbar-menubar.jpeg?ssl=1\" alt=\"BitBar in action\" data-image-w=\"\" data-image-h=\"\" class=\" jetpack-broken-image\" data-recalc-dims=\"1\"><figcaption>Three BitBar plugins in action.</figcaption></figure><p>I really can’t recommend Mat Ryer’s <a href=\"https://github.com/matryer/bitbar\">BitBar</a> enough. It’s a free Mac utility that lets you put more or less anything you want in your menu bar. I keep finding more uses for it—at this point I’ve got four separate BitBar items in my menu bar.</p>\n<p>At its simplest, BitBar is an app that runs plug-ins that display information in your menu bar. (It’s named because it was initially built to display Bitcoin prices.) There’s a whole collection of plug-ins at <a href=\"http://getbitbar.com\">getbitbar.com</a>, so if you’re not comfortable writing your own, you might find exactly what you want. It’s also easy to modify existing plugins to do what you want—all a BitBar plugin is, is a script that runs, gets data, and then returns a value that is displayed in the menu bar.</p>\n<p>Last week a friend of mine upgraded to Catalina and, in the process, lost an old Mac utility he used to display the currently playing track in iTunes/Apple Music. I suggested he look at BitBar, which has a <a href=\"https://github.com/matryer/bitbar-plugins/blob/master/Music/music.10s.sh\">plugin that does just that</a>.</p>\n<p>It turns out that while it worked, BitBar’s plugin didn’t do exactly what he wanted. Most notably, he wanted the current track to be displayed in the format <code>Song Title - Album (Year) - Artist</code>. Since this particular plugin was a shell script, I was able to open it in BBEdit and quickly <a href=\"https://pastebin.com/UfBX9H4k\">customize it</a> to meet his needs.</p>\n<p>For example, the existing music plug-in didn’t display the year, but I was able to include a little bit of inline AppleScript within the shell script that did the trick:</p>\n<pre><code>year=$(osascript -e'\nset theYear to \"0\"\ntell application \"Music\"\n    try\n        set theYear to (year of current track as string)\n    on error errText\n        \"\"\n    end try\nend tell\nif theYear = \"0\" then\n    return \"\"\nelse\n    return (\"(\" &#38; theYear &#38; \")\")\nend if\n');\n</code></pre>\n<p>I also ripped out a bunch of features that my friend didn’t really want, like play/pause/next/previous controls and a bunch of metadata in the dropdown menu. (Yes, BitBar will let you not just create custom text in the menu bar, but in the items that display when you click on the menu bar item.)</p>\n<p>Last week Dan Moren updated a plug-in that I wrote a while back that looks at the live-stream servers of our various podcast networks and displays the current number of listeners in the menu bar. (He re-wrote the thing in PHP, since that’s a language he’s comfortable with.)</p>\n<p>I’ve also got the current temperature from my weather station in my menu bar thanks to BitBar. Since I was more comfortable writing in AppleScript than in a shell script, my weather “plugin” is a single line – <code>osascript ~/weatherscript.scpt</code> – that runs a small AppleScript script that queries my weather station and returns the current temperature data, which BitBar displays.</p>\n<p>Finally, I use a tiny plugin that pings my Linode server and reports back the total ping time, which is useful in determining at a glance if I’m really having network issues or if it’s just my imagination.</p>\n<p>If you’re comfortable in literally any scripting language that can execute on your Mac, you can build BitBar plugins to display anything you can think of in your menu bar.</p>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Wed, 19 Aug 2020 19:17:41 +0000","feedId":1506,"bgimg":"https://i0.wp.com/sixcolors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/bitbar-menubar.jpeg?ssl=1","linkMd5":"93a9fa365f0a2dba6e161cc2699a120f","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn3@2020_2/2020/08/24/18-19-08-801_7a0d26b02ac4f692.webp","destWidth":1360,"destHeight":48,"sourceBytes":18191,"destBytes":11836,"author":"Jason Snell","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i0.wp.com/sixcolors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/bitbar-menubar.jpeg?ssl=1":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn3@2020_2/2020/08/24/18-19-08-801_7a0d26b02ac4f692.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598293144111},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 02:19:04","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 02:19:04","title":"(Podcast) The Rebound #297: Eat It, Spielberg","link":"https://sixcolors.com/?p=11850","description":"<p>This is a great time for sitting at home and watching things so let’s talk about what’s on the telly. There are a few nice details in the article about Fluegelman’s enthusiasm for the original Macintosh:</p>\n<blockquote><p>\n  The <em>PC World</em> issue with the landmark review of PC-File was still on newsstands when Andrew Fluegelman had his next life-changing encounter with a computer: he was one of a select few invited to Apple for an early unveiling of the new Macintosh. href=\"http://reboundcast.com/episode/302\">Go to the podcast page</a>.</p>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Wed, 12 Aug 2020 17:42:51 +0000","feedId":1506,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"ae8ce35e05306769c541803a4dad4634","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"Dan Moren","publishedOrCreatedDate":1598293144124},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 02:19:04","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 02:19:04","title":"Quick Tip: Convert high-efficiency iPhone images to JPEG","link":"http://two.wordpress.test/post/2020/04/quick_tip_convert_high-efficiency_iphone_images_to_jpeg/","description":"<p>I shared this tip in the Six Colors member Slack<sup id=\"fnref-10893-membership\"><a href=\"https://sixcolors.com#fn-10893-membership\" class=\"jetpack-footnote\">1</a></sup> not long ago, but it occurred to me as I used it again this morning that others might find it helpful.</p>\n<p>Prior to iOS 11, all Apple devices with cameras shot images as a bog-standard JPG. But after, most of Apple’s modern devices have offered a new option: the High-Efficiency Image Format or HEIF.<sup id=\"fnref-10893-heic\"><a href=\"https://sixcolors.com#fn-10893-heic\" class=\"jetpack-footnote\">2</a></sup> HEIF’s advantages are clear: they take up about half the space of a commensurate quality JPEG and they support animation, like a GIF, but at better quality and smaller file sizes.<sup id=\"fnref-10893-hevc\"><a href=\"https://sixcolors.com#fn-10893-hevc\" class=\"jetpack-footnote\">3</a></sup></p>\n<p>However, HEIF is not as widely supported as JPEG, which has been around forever and is the de facto image format. In fact, iOS often automatically converts the pictures to JPEG if you upload them to some websites, including social media platforms.</p>\n<p>But if you, as I occasionally do, AirDrop these photos to the Mac, they come across as HEIF files rather than JPEGs.<sup id=\"fnref-10893-edited\"><a href=\"https://sixcolors.com#fn-10893-edited\" class=\"jetpack-footnote\">4</a></sup> And trying to upload them to websites or share them with people may thus lead to problems.</p>\n<p>To solve this issue, I whipped up the smallest Automator workflow ever to let me easily convert these files to JPEGs. Follow the below steps to recreate it, or, if you’d rather, just <a href=\"https://sixcolors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/convert.zip\">download the version I made</a>.</p>\n<figure><img src=\"https://i1.wp.com/sixcolors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/automator-converttojpg-6c.jpg?ssl=1\" alt=\"Convert to JPEG workflow\" data-image-w=\"\" data-image-h=\"\" class=\" jetpack-broken-image\" data-recalc-dims=\"1\"><figcaption>Probably the simplest Automator workflow ever.</figcaption></figure><p>Fire up Automator and create a new Quick Action workflow. At the top, choose “image files” from the “Workflow receives current” drop-down menu, and “Finder.app” for the application. Then, in the search box above the actions section, find the “Change Type of Images” action and drag it into the main workspace. (Automator will offer you the option to add an action retaining the original HEIF images—that’s up to you, but I chose “Don’t Add” because the originals are usually still on my phone.)</p>\n<p>In the Change Type of Images dropdown, choose JPEG from the dropdown menu. Save the workflow and give the Quick Action a name like “Convert to JPEG”.</p>\n<figure class=\"pull-right\"><img src=\"https://i2.wp.com/sixcolors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/Finder-quickaction-convert2-6c.jpg?ssl=1\" alt=\"Quick Action menu\" data-image-w=\"\" data-image-h=\"\" class=\" jetpack-broken-image\" data-recalc-dims=\"1\"><figcaption></figcaption></figure><p>Now, in the Finder, whenever you have an HEIF file (or any image file) you can right click on it and go to Quick Actions, then choose the new “Convert to JPEG” action you made, and, voilÃ ! A JPG version of the same file will appear near instantaneously. (You can also click the Quick Action button in the preview pane, if you have that displayed.) You can then go ahead and upload that image wherever you’d like.</p>\n<p>You can, of course, avoid this by switching your iOS device’s default to shooting in traditional JPEG instead, by going to Settings &#62; Camera &#62; Formats and choosing “Most Compatible”, but be aware that it means you will be taking up more space. Apple also doesn’t offer granular options for changing formats for still photos vs. video—it’s an all or none proposition.</p>\n<div class=\"footnotes\">\n<hr><ol><li id=\"fn-10893-membership\">\nOne of the many perks of being a <a href=\"https://sixcolors.com/subscribe/\">Six Colors subscriber</a>! <a href=\"https://sixcolors.com#fnref-10893-membership\"><img src=\"https://s.w.org/images/core/emoji/13.0.0/72x72/21a9.png\" alt=\"↩\" class=\"wp-smiley\" style=\"height: 1em; max-height: 1em;\" /></a>\n</li>\n<li id=\"fn-10893-heic\">\nApple has also at times referred to this format as HEIC, and confusingly, the suffix used by those files on the Mac is .heic. The ‘C’ stands for…cool? [<em>It’s Container, because a HEIC file can contain multiple items, including HEIF images.</em> <strong>—j.s.</strong>] <a href=\"https://sixcolors.com#fnref-10893-heic\"><img src=\"https://s.w.org/images/core/emoji/13.0.0/72x72/21a9.png\" alt=\"↩\" class=\"wp-smiley\" style=\"height: 1em; max-height: 1em;\" /></a>\n</li>\n<li id=\"fn-10893-hevc\">\nThere’s also an equivalent for video, HEVC. <a href=\"https://sixcolors.com#fnref-10893-hevc\"><img src=\"https://s.w.org/images/core/emoji/13.0.0/72x72/21a9.png\" alt=\"↩\" class=\"wp-smiley\" style=\"height: 1em; max-height: 1em;\" /></a>\n</li>\n<li id=\"fn-10893-edited\">\nSometimes, anyway? I’ve noticed that occasionally they transfer as JPEGs—I think if you edit them on device, including simply rotating them, they’re converted to JPEGs. And if the device you’re AirDropping to doesn’t support HEIF or HEVC, it’ll automatically be converted to a compatible format. <a href=\"https://sixcolors.com#fnref-10893-edited\"><img src=\"https://s.w.org/images/core/emoji/13.0.0/72x72/21a9.png\" alt=\"↩\" class=\"wp-smiley\" style=\"height: 1em;
