(I picture the “Template Gun” as more of a hot-dog or t-shirt cannon.)</p>\n<p>The premise is that I keep a folder full of zip archives containing the Logic Pro projects and asset files for all of my podcasts. Template Gun launches, providing me a list of all my current templates, and when I pick one it’s automatically unzipped on my Desktop, ready to go to work.</p>\n<p>If you regularly find yourself building project folders (of any kind!) from scratch in the Finder, I highly recommend the concept of making yourself a zip archive you can use as a ready-made template. And if you’re got multiple templates to choose from, something like my Template Gun script sure beats leaving them all on your Desktop or fishing them out of a folder.</p>\n<p>But one of my favorite features of Template Gun is that, after it unzips the template, it does some helpful renaming of the resulting folder and files in order go get it ready for my use. Back in 2018, I wrote about how Template Gun was taking the current date, subtracting it from the launch date of my podcasts, and then using that to give my podcast files the proper episode number.</p>\n<p>This seemed logical to me at the time, but now it seems ridiculous. For two reasons:</p>\n<ul><li>Sometimes I do two podcasts in a week; sometimes I skip weeks. It’s been 493 weeks since I launched <a href=\"https://www.theincomparable.com\">The Incomparable</a>, but this weekend I’m posting episode 500. Using week offsets means you have to edit the script every time you don’t release one single episode per week.\n</li>\n<li>\n<p>The part of my brain that conceives of automating tasks on my Mac is, apparently, still mired in 1995—an era where connectivity to the Internet could not be assumed. When I build Shortcuts on iOS, I constantly avail myself of web services. My scripts on the Mac are meant to be run without any network around. It’s 2020. This is stupid.</p>\n</li>\n</ul><p>Which brings me to my revelation: If there’s an Internet-based source that can tell me the current episode number of my podcast, I can just look it up there and increment by one, creating the template for the next episode. Every podcast has an RSS feed. We can do this.</p>\n<pre><code>set theFeed to (do shell script \"curl https://www.relay.fm/upgrade/feed\")\n</code></pre>\n<p>Once again, <code>do shell script</code> is the MVP of scripting on macOS, because it lets me hand off commands to helpful unix tools like <code>curl</code>, which goes and fetches the entire contents of any URL.</p>\n<pre><code>set theFeed to (characters 1 thru 2000 of theFeed) as string\n</code></pre>\n<p>Then I parse the first 2000 characters of the feed — that’s all I need, and podcast RSS feeds are big.</p>\n<pre><code>set theEpisode to item 2 of (getmatch(theFeed, \"&#60;title&#62;Upgrade ([0-9]+)\"))\n</code></pre>\n<p>Now I’m using Michael Klement’s <a href=\"https://sixcolors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/applescript-grep.txt\">helpful <code>getmatch</code> subroutine</a> to do a regular-expression search<sup id=\"fnref-4095-grep\"><a href=\"https://sixcolors.com#fn-4095-grep\" class=\"jetpack-footnote\">1</a></sup> to grab the first episode number to appear in the feed.</p>\n<pre><code>set theEpisode to ((theEpisode as integer) + 1)\n</code></pre>\n<p>Increment the integer by one, and we’ve got our new episode number.</p>\n<p>The CMS we’ve built for The Incomparable generates a semicolon-delimited stats file for every podcast, so for my Incomparable podcasts I have to parse slightly differently:</p>\n<pre><code>set theResult to (do shell script \"curl https://www.theincomparable.com/vulcanhello/stats.txt\")\nset theStart to (characters 1 thru 6 of theResult) as string\nset theEpisode to (characters 1 thru ((offset of \";\" in theStart) - 1) of theStart) as string\nset episodeCount to ((theEpisode as integer) + 1)\n</code></pre>\n<p>And for podcasts that don’t have episode numbers, I fall back on dates:</p>\n<pre><code>if mychoice contains \"Six Colors\" then\nset todaysDay to day of (current date) as string\nset theMonth to month of (current date) as string\nset theYear to (year of (current date)) as string\nset theNewName to (\"sixcolors-\" &#38; theMonth &#38; \"-\" &#38; todaysDay &#38; \"-\" &#38; theYear)\ntell application \"System Events\"\n    set name of file (theDesktop &#38; \"Six Colors:sixcolors.logicx\") to (theNewName &#38; \".logicx\")\n    set name of folder (theDesktop &#38; \"Six Colors\") to theNewName\nend tell\nend if\n</code></pre>\n<p>It’s a nice touch that reduces the amount of work I need to do to prep my workspace and begin the real work at hand. If you could see yourself using something like this to get your job done, feel free to <a href=\"https://sixcolors.com/post/2020/02/template-gun-feb2020.txt\">look at my AppleScript source code</a>. And don’t forget: the Internet is a wonderful resource that your scripts can use to save you effort.</p>\n<div class=\"footnotes\">\n<hr><ol><li id=\"fn-4095-grep\">\nSeriously, if you write AppleScript scripts, you need these subroutines. Having grep available in my scripts has been transformative. <a href=\"https://sixcolors.com#fnref-4095-grep\"><img src=\"https://s.w.org/images/core/emoji/13.0.0/72x72/21a9.png\" alt=\"↩\" class=\"wp-smiley\" style=\"height: 1em; max-height: 1em;\" /></a>\n</li>\n</ol></div>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 07 Feb 2020 10:30:00 +0000","feedId":1506,"bgimg":"https://i2.wp.com/sixcolors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/template-gun-web-6c.jpg?ssl=1","linkMd5":"f419b807429fc197b57d966a9a756e59","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn84@2020_1/2020/08/24/18-19-08-655_1869cdaa18efb7b5.webp","destWidth":1360,"destHeight":440,"sourceBytes":24474,"destBytes":24474,"author":"Jason Snell","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i2.wp.com/sixcolors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/template-gun-web-6c.jpg?ssl=1":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn84@2020_1/2020/08/24/18-19-08-655_1869cdaa18efb7b5.webp","https://s.w.org/images/core/emoji/13.0.0/72x72/21a9.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn51@2020_2/2020/08/24/18-19-11-215_25686225908fe44d.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598293144632},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 02:19:04","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 02:19:04","title":"iPhones without chargers ↦","link":"https://sixcolors.com/?p=11688","description":"<p>David Sparks <a href=\"https://www.macsparky.com/blog/2020/7/the-iphone-sans-charger-debate\">comments on the rumors</a> that the new iPhones won’t ship with power adapters in their boxes:</p>\n<blockquote><p>\n  If I were Apple, I’d be looking at ways to ship the phone without a charger or cord, but also have some mechanism where, if customers need those things, they get them with zero delay, friction, or cost. Apple is a pretty smart company. They can figure it out.\n</p></blockquote>\n<p>Yes. What Apple needs to communicate is that they are doing this <a href=\"https://www.theverge.com/2020/6/30/21307463/apple-iphone-12-power-adapter-charger-rumor-usb-c\">because of waste</a> and not because they want to nickel-and-dime the customers who are paying a lot of money for a new iPhone.</p>\n<p>The most straightforward way to do this is be to allow iPhone buyers to request an adapter for free (or for a <em>very</em> modest handling fee) when they buy an iPhone. If you need it, take it. If you have plenty of adapters, don’t.</p><p><a href=\"https://www.macsparky.com/blog/2020/7/the-iphone-sans-charger-debate\">Go to the linked site</a>.</p><p><a href=\"https://sixcolors.com/link/2020/07/iphones-without-chargers/\">Read on Six Colors</a>.</p>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 03 Jul 2020 21:07:06 +0000","feedId":1506,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"d21ae478868dac9111686004a0dfee2d","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"Jason Snell","publishedOrCreatedDate":1598293144174},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 02:19:04","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 02:19:04","title":"Project xCloud Preview impressions: More than playable, less than perfect","link":"http://two.wordpress.test/post/2020/02/project_xcloud_preview_impressions_more_than_playable_less_than_perfect/","description":"<p>I’d probably shock twelve-year-old me if I went back in time and told him that for the last thirteen years I’d been an avid user of a game console built by none other than Microsoft.<sup id=\"fnref-11032-timetravel\"><a href=\"https://sixcolors.com#fn-11032-timetravel\" class=\"jetpack-footnote\">1</a></sup> But here I am, on my second Xbox, and I remain pretty happy with my gaming choices over the past decade and change.</p>\n<p>That said, I also own a Nintendo Switch, which has the benefit of being able to go wherever I do. The Xbox doesn’t match that portability…yet.</p>\n<p>A few weeks back, I signed up for beta access to Microsoft’s new Project xCloud game streaming service, right on the heels of its availability on iOS. (Though Microsoft had announced the service would support the iPhone and iPad, earlier betas had only worked on Android.) I’ve spent a little bit of time with it over the past couple weeks, and though it’s not without its flaws, I’ve come away impressed at what Microsoft has put together, even in this early stage.</p>\n<figure><img src=\"https://i0.wp.com/sixcolors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/xcloud-home.jpg?ssl=1\" alt=\"Project xCloud\" data-image-w=\"\" data-image-h=\"\" class=\" jetpack-broken-image\" data-recalc-dims=\"1\"><figcaption>The interface for Project xCloud is straightforward, and spartan.</figcaption></figure><p>The idea behind Project xCloud is simple: use an app on your smartphone or tablet to stream console games. You’ll also need a Bluetooth-compatible Xbox controller which, thanks to iOS 13, can easily be paired with your iOS devices.<sup id=\"fnref-11032-dualshock\"><a href=\"https://sixcolors.com#fn-11032-dualshock\" class=\"jetpack-footnote\">2</a></sup> During the preview period, Microsoft doesn’t require users to own an Xbox console or the games—it’s unclear what the final finished product will require.<sup id=\"fnref-11032-consolestreaming\"><a href=\"https://sixcolors.com#fn-11032-consolestreaming\" class=\"jetpack-footnote\">3</a></sup></p>\n<p>While the Android version of the preview apparently supports more than 50 games, the iOS version currently only offers a “single” title: Microsoft’s own <em>Halo: The Master Chief Collection</em>, which includes the first six <em>Halo</em> games, including updated versions of <em>Halo</em> and <em>Halo 2</em>. These are obviously good showcase titles for Microsoft, given that the newest game on there, <em>Halo 4</em>, is from 2012, so they aren’t as graphically intensive as games being released in 2020. But they’re not without their own inherent challenges: <em>Halo</em> is a very twitch-oriented first-person shooter series, meaning that running into problems with latency can significantly affect gameplay—especially in multiplayer.</p>\n<p>I’ve spent most of my time in the single-player campaign of the original <em>Halo</em>‘s 2011 remaster, since it’s a game I’ve played only a little, and I’ve been mostly impressed with the performance. Though there is definitely some lag at times (especially with sound effects, weirdly), I haven’t felt that it impacted my enjoyment of the game—or, perhaps I’m more forgiving, given the title’s age.</p>\n<p>I did try a little bit of <em>Halo 3</em> multiplayer, something that I spent a lot of time with in its heyday, and I acquitted myself reasonably. Though I definitely experienced some lag here and there, I didn’t feel like it hurt me more significantly than my rustiness at the game, though I did find myself cranking up the look sensitivity to make the controls feel more responsive.</p>\n<figure><img src=\"https://i2.wp.com/sixcolors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/xcloud-halo1.jpg?ssl=1\" alt=\"Halo: Reach\" data-image-w=\"\" data-image-h=\"\" class=\" jetpack-broken-image\" data-recalc-dims=\"1\"><p>&#60;</p>\n<p>figcaption&#62;Graphics in games like <em>Halo: Reach</em> are passable, but not up to console standards.</p></figure><p>Graphics are a mixed bag: playing on my 10.5-inch iPad Pro, they were sometimes crystal clear, and other times—especially in outdoor scenes on <em>Halo</em>‘s eponymous ring—somewhat muddy and pixelated. Scenes that seemed less graphically demanding, such as driving through underground tunnels, were far clearer. It’s possible to chalk up some of this to my Internet connection or router, though my speed tests regularly register 100 Mbps downstream, which is far in excess of the 10Mbps connection Microsoft says is required. (I did occasionally get a notification saying my connection was weak.) Project xCloud does support cellular networks as well, but I’m not sure I’m willing to put my data plan through that as yet.</p>\n<p>Speaking of usage, Project xCloud will definitely chew through your battery—but that’s no surprise, given the demands on graphics and CPU, display, and both the Internet and Bluetooth connections. Your mileage may, of course, vary, but don’t expect this to be an all-day gaming affair—or, at least, bring a charger.</p>\n<figure><img src=\"https://i2.wp.com/sixcolors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/xcloud-halo-3.jpg?ssl=1\" alt=\"Halo: Combat Evolved\" data-image-w=\"\" data-image-h=\"\" class=\" jetpack-broken-image\" data-recalc-dims=\"1\"><figcaption>The remastered version of the original *Halo* looks good, but isn’t without its glitches.</figcaption></figure><p>There’s also the challenge of playing on a much smaller screen than usual, which raises questions of viewing angles and reading onscreen text. My first attempt at playing games was with my iPhone 11 Pro and I quickly understood why Microsoft recommends <a href=\"https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/p/powera-moga-mobile-gaming-clip-for-xbox/8rtf503l2pl9\">a clip for attaching your phone to your controller</a>. Even propped up in a stand at the correct angle, getting close enough to the screen to see details like the HUD was a (often literal) pain.</p>\n<p>I fared better on my 10.5-inch iPad Pro, though even there I still had trouble at times arranging it at the right height. But using the Smart Keyboard in its “stand” arrangement wasn’t too bad for playing at my desk.</p>\n<p>Using the Xbox controller was perhaps the best part of the experience, since it required no adaptation on my part whatsoever (other than making sure <em>Halo</em> was using my preferred control scheme). Supposedly xCloud will allow developers to roll out custom touch controls for games, though on something like an FPS, it’s really hard to match the precision of a controller, as many iOS game developers have discovered over the years.</p>\n<p>That said, I did run into some issues with the controller where buttons didn’t react immediately and then sometimes “caught up,” resulting in double shots, or in some cases, turning an automatic weapon into a semi-automatic. In the original <em>Halo</em> in particular, the zoom functionality of the sniper rifle, which has both a 2x and 10x level was <em>especially</em> unreliable, requiring me to mash the button several times to get to the higher zoom.</p>\n<p>Out of curiosity, I did at one point try to mirror my iPad’s display to my Apple TV to see if I could use it as though it were a console, but the graphics and sound stuttered unplayably. (Again, it’s quite possibly that my setup may be part of the problem there.) I’ll be interested to see if Microsoft will consider porting the app to the Apple TV, or if that would hew too close to its Xbox business.</p>\n<figure><img src=\"https://i0.wp.com/sixcolors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/xcloud-halo2.jpg?ssl=1\" alt=\"Halo: Reach\" data-image-w=\"\" data-image-h=\"\" class=\" jetpack-broken-image\" data-recalc-dims=\"1\"></figure><p>I’m not sure if I want to play an entire console game via a streaming setup, but depending on how xCloud pricing and availability work out—things that Microsoft hasn’t discussed yet—it could be an attractive option for those who don’t want to invest in yet another console. And, as an Xbox owner, the ability to pick up and play where I left off on my console while I’m on the go—one of the major selling points of the Nintendo Switch—has a lot of appeal.</p>\n<p>And, obviously, Microsoft’s not alone in this streaming market: Google has already launched its own offering, Stadia, though initial reviews have not been unequivocally positive. It’ll be interesting to see how these two competitors build out their services in terms of not only the quality of streaming offered, but also the game libraries. Given Microsoft’s existing status in the game market, it may have to worry more about cutting into sales of its hardware—though I imagine that whatever is offered in Project xCloud will not come close to what will be available on its next-generation Xbox Series X console, due later this year. Then again, for those of us who want to catch up on a whole generation of games that we may have missed, streaming older titles may be just fine.</p>\n<p>But for a service that is only in beta so far, Project xCloud feels remarkably solid, if still in need of improvement. It’ll be interesting to see how that progresses throughout the beta process and into the final product.</p>\n<div class=\"footnotes\">\n<hr><ol><li id=\"fn-11032-timetravel\">\nAlso, he’d probably be wondering what the hell happened to all his hair? <a href=\"https://sixcolors.com#fnref-11032-timetravel\"><img src=\"https://s.w.org/images/core/emoji/13.0.0/72x72/21a9.png\" alt=\"↩\" class=\"wp-smiley\" style=\"height: 1em; max-height: 1em;\" /></a>\n</li>\n<li id=\"fn-11032-dualshock\">\nSupposedly Sony’s Dual Shock controller will be supported in the future as well. <a href=\"https://sixcolors.com#fnref-11032-dualshock\"><img src=\"https://s.w.org/images/core/emoji/13.0.0/72x72/21a9.png\" alt=\"↩\" class=\"wp-smiley\" style=\"height: 1em; max-height: 1em;\" /></a>\n</li>\n<li id=\"fn-11032-consolestreaming\">\nConfusingly, Microsoft also has a beta of a Console Streaming program that lets you stream games you own directly from your Xbox to a mobile device. It’s unclear how these two services will intersect or differ when they’re finally released. <a href=\"https://sixcolors.com#fnref-11032-consolestreaming\"><img src=\"https://s.w.org/images/core/emoji/13.0.0/72x72/21a9.png\" alt=\"↩\" class=\"wp-smiley\" style=\"height: 1em; max-height: 1em;\" /></a>\n</li>\n</ol></div>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 28 Feb 2020 19:00:00 +0000","feedId":1506,"bgimg":"https://i0.wp.com/sixcolors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/xcloud-home.jpg?ssl=1","linkMd5":"4161b83620b0d1d970554c9d92eb2b0e","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn43@2020_3/2020/08/24/18-19-08-501_b622aef3abb365ea.webp","destWidth":1360,"destHeight":1020,"sourceBytes":25812,"destBytes":25812,"author":"Dan Moren","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i0.wp.com/sixcolors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/xcloud-home.jpg?ssl=1":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn43@2020_3/2020/08/24/18-19-08-501_b622aef3abb365ea.webp","https://i2.wp.com/sixcolors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/xcloud-halo1.jpg?ssl=1":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn91@2020_4/2020/08/24/18-19-15-611_b68f114c91660e83.webp","https://i2.wp.com/sixcolors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/xcloud-halo-3.jpg?ssl=1":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn64@2020_2/2020/08/24/18-19-16-358_ea254a18b3b2b57f.webp","https://i0.wp.com/sixcolors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/xcloud-halo2.jpg?ssl=1":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn24@2020_6/2020/08/24/18-19-13-312_54cbba0e7b4074cd.webp","https://s.w.org/images/core/emoji/13.0.0/72x72/21a9.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn51@2020_2/2020/08/24/18-19-11-215_25686225908fe44d.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598293144613},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 02:19:04","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 02:19:04","title":"20 Macs for 2020: #18 – Xserve","link":"https://sixcolors.com/?p=12657","description":"<p>It’s 2020, and Apple is shipping a <a href=\"https://twitter.com/brianstucki/status/1219299028791226368\">rack-mountable Mac Pro</a>. It’s the latest chapter in a decades-long flirtation between Apple and the machines that dwell in the server closet. Even though the Mac Pro is rack-mountable, Apple can’t quite see it as a server—<a href=\"https://twitter.com/brianstucki/status/1217136324219568128\">you can’t buy it without a mouse and keyboard</a>. Instead, the company seems content to let individual users and dedicated third parties like MacStadium do the work of taking Mac workstations and treating them like they belong in a server rack.</p>\n<p>This is a subject that’s close to my heart. I’ve only had my name on a single printed book and it was called “<a href=\"https://www.worldcat.org/title/providing-internet-services-via-the-mac-os/oclc/34243972\">Providing Internet Services via the Mac OS</a>,” and told you everything you needed to know to turn a Mac running Classic Mac OS into a server. (Yes, that was a thing that we did back then.) From the mid-90s through the early 2000s, I had a series of Macs running classic Mac OS in my closet that acted as web, email, FTP, and database servers. Here’s to the crazy ones, I guess.</p>\n<p>Apple has always been a consumer hardware company through and through, not a company that makes servers or speaks to an audience of IT people and network managers. But that hasn’t stopped it from trying. In the ’90s, Apple would rebadge Power Macs as Apple Workgroup Servers, bundling them with extra hardware and software.</p>\n<figure class=\"pull-right\"><img src=\"https://i1.wp.com/sixcolors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/shiner.jpeg?ssl=1\" alt=\"\" data-image-w=\"\" data-image-h=\"\" class=\" jetpack-broken-image\" data-recalc-dims=\"1\"><figcaption>Shiner. (Not a Mac.)</figcaption></figure><p>I started covering Apple in the mid-90s, and let me tell you, that particular version of Apple was extremely weird, as epitomized by the <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PsVAdrdkyoA\">Apple Network Server</a>, code-named Shiner.</p>\n<p>Shiner was not a Mac. Shiner was a PowerPC-based server that cost between $11,000 and $15,000, and ran IBM’s version of UNIX known as AIX—which you needed to buy separately, for an additional $1,600. It was delayed several times, as its competitive advantage over PCs running Novell NetWare continued to dissipate. Robert Hess of MacWEEK wrote in 1995 that Apple had “missed its window of opportunity.” Reviews were positive, but tempered with a skepticism (later proven right) that Apple would actually commit to making a line of Unix-based servers.</p>\n<p>Like most mid-90s Apple products, Shiner was killed off in 1997 as Apple was gripped by its near-death experience. “I look at that as a dream when Apple was in a coma,” Steve Jobs later said, while insisting that what would come next would be entirely different.</p>\n<p>In fact,  the arrival of Jobs actually planted the seed of Apple’s next attempt to fit in a server rack: NextStep, the operating system that would evolve into Mac OS X, was based on Unix. The door was open for a Mac to be a real live Unix-based server and it took Apple almost no time to build its own server hardware.</p>\n<p>It was OS X. On a server. It was Xserve. Pronounced like the letter, not the roman numeral. No, I don’t know why. Apple did stuff like that back in 2002.</p>\n<figure><img src=\"https://i2.wp.com/sixcolors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/06-xserve_front.jpeg?ssl=1\" alt=\"\" data-image-w=\"\" data-image-h=\"\" class=\" jetpack-broken-image\" data-recalc-dims=\"1\"><figcaption></figcaption></figure><p>The Steve Jobs and Jony Ive era of Apple was a design heyday when Apple created many interesting, clever, and influential products. The Xserve was… not that. It was most definitely the sign of a design team trying to figure out how to add some flair and creativity to a place—the server rack—that did not care one bit about either of those.</p>\n<figure class=\"pull-right\"><img src=\"https://i2.wp.com/sixcolors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/08-xserve_rack.jpeg?ssl=1\" alt=\"\" data-image-w=\"\" data-image-h=\"\" class=\" jetpack-broken-image\" data-recalc-dims=\"1\"><figcaption>Xserve was designed to live in the server rack.</figcaption></figure><p>Sized specifically for server racks, it was what’s called a 1U server, meaning it was a single unit high—so 1.75 inches thick, to go with the dimensions of a 19-inch equipment rack. Those dimensions are unusually large for a Mac: 18 inches wide and 28 inches deep. This was not a pizza box. This was an extra-extra-large, party-size pizza box.</p>\n<p>Apple has frequently struggled between its instinct to create beautiful designs and designs that make its products more functional. Some of Apple’s worst design missteps have come because looks were prioritized over usability. (Feel free to think of your favorite example now. I’m imagining a round Mac Pro and an ultra-thin keyboard with no key travel.)</p>\n<p>Xserve, then, was a real design challenge. How do you take pride in creating something for a server rack, the most utilitarian of environments? I’m not here to tell you Xserve was pretty, because it wasn’t. But it’s clear Apple’s designers struggled mightily to give it a little extra something.</p>\n<p>The pretty stuff was on the front—fitting, since that’s really the only part you could see. There were shiny buttons, a FireWire 400 port, a slimline CD-ROM drive, and four hot-swappable hard drive modules. Press the front of a module and once the drive dismounted, a light appeared, indicating it was safe to remove the disk.</p>\n<p>The back side featured a standard array of ports for the time, room for ports from three expansion cards, and the notably weird PC-standard DB-9 serial port. The idea was that you could connect to the Xserve and gain command-line access via serial, even if it wasn’t on your network. It’s a choice that makes sense for a server, but it’s pretty wacky for a Mac.</p>\n<p>There was so much room inside that Xserve case that Apple designed it with two fans. The idea was that if one fan became less capable, the other fan would adjust to compensate—and if you needed to swap a fan out, you could do so without shutting the computer down.</p>\n<p>Those fans are another of the Xserve’s unusual qualities: This is undoubtedly, indisputably the loudest Mac ever made. If people thought they could tuck these in a server rack in their quiet studio space, they were wrong… those fans <em>howled</em>. This was a server designed to be put away in a closet or server installation.</p>\n<figure class=\"pull-right\"><img src=\"https://i1.wp.com/sixcolors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/02-xserveraid_3q.jpeg?ssl=1\" alt=\"\" data-image-w=\"\" data-image-h=\"\" class=\" jetpack-broken-image\" data-recalc-dims=\"1\"><figcaption>Xserve RAID.</figcaption></figure><p>The Xserve also inspired the creation of one of Apple’s most unusual Mac accessories this side of the Duo Dock: The Xserve RAID. This was a 3U high 14-disk hard drive array with a design to match the Xserve.</p>\n<p>The early 2000s were an era when Apple was so excited by the prospect of Mac OS X’s Unix underpinnings that it designed a rack-mountable Mac server and a 14-disk RAID system. “We have a lot to learn, but I think we’re going to learn fast, and learn by working with some great customers,” Jobs said on the day of the Xserve’s unveiling. But by the end of the decade it was clear that this was an area best served by other companies—not Apple.</p>\n<p>Over the decades, Apple’s instinct for identifying the core of its business has been good, but there have been exceptions at the fringes. It created Aperture thinking it would take on Adobe for the high-end photography market… and then thought better of it.</p>\n<p>Xserve is a similar example. The company saw a niche market where it could make something cooler and better and more cutting edge. But every other strategic decision Apple made during that era was in the service of its core business of making personal computers. Xserve survived eight years, including the transition to Intel, but it could not have been a hard decision for Apple to discontinue it and steer people who needed Mac servers to the Mac Pro and Mac mini.</p>\n<p>Mac servers never died. They’re still all over the place, operated by people who are more comfortable with macOS than the alternatives. I’ve had a Mac mini running as a server in my house since the first one arrived on the scene. And yes, that rack-mountable Mac Pro is now available.</p>\n<p>But the Xserve will always stand alone. It was the only Mac made specifically for that equipment rack. I’d ask for us to take a moment of silence to remember it, but you wouldn’t be able to hear yourself think over the fan noise.</p>\n<figure class=\"youtube\"><p><iframe width=\"560\" height=\"315\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/WSS4fWf0cDU\" frameborder=\"0\" allow=\"accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture\" allowfullscreen></iframe></p>\n</figure><p>I’ll be back next week with number 17.</p>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 17 Aug 2020 16:00:12 +0000","feedId":1506,"bgimg":"https://i1.wp.com/sixcolors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/shiner.jpeg?ssl=1","linkMd5":"8f70e4311223f4879466151341fd5770","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn63@2020_3/2020/08/24/18-19-10-135_fcb1c29a9694851a.webp","destWidth":680,"destHeight":731,"sourceBytes":135895,"destBytes":54308,"author":"Jason Snell","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i1.wp.com/sixcolors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/shiner.jpeg?ssl=1":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn63@2020_3/2020/08/24/18-19-10-135_fcb1c29a9694851a.webp","https://i2.wp.com/sixcolors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/06-xserve_front.jpeg?ssl=1":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn23@2020_4/2020/08/24/18-19-17-528_6d24dcf56b7c666b.jpg","https://i2.wp.com/sixcolors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/08-xserve_rack.jpeg?ssl=1":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn20@2020_1/2020/08/24/18-19-12-254_f1400cd894c6126b.jpg","https://i1.wp.com/sixcolors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/02-xserveraid_3q.jpeg?ssl=1":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn86@2020_1/2020/08/24/18-19-12-348_fddb257f29b37868.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598293144138},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 02:19:04","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 02:19:04","title":"Time for Apple to reevaluate how the App Store does business (Macworld/Dan Moren)","link":"https://sixcolors.com/?p=12536","description":"<p>If there’s a segment of Apple’s business that seems to fly in the face of the company’s philosophy—not just in terms of making a product that is substandard or lackluster—but in terms of actually being at odds with the way it otherwise does business, you couldn’t put forth a more prominent example than the App Store.</p>\n<p>The discussion, always at a constant simmer in the Apple community, bubbled up once again last week even as Apple CEO Tim Cook was grilled by lawmakers over antitrust concerns. Developers, regularly dissatisfied with the company’s lack of transparency and equality over rules, took the opportunity to renew criticism of not only that, but the hefty 30-percent cut of proceeds.</p>\n<p>The App Store has been a profitable business for both developers and Apple in the decade-plus since its launch, but there’s a strong argument that as much of its benefits have accrued to those making the apps that feed it, just as much—if not more—has found its way into the coffers of the platform owner. Enough so that the company has built an entire fast-growing segment of its income around Services, amongst which the App Store is undoubtedly the crown jewel.</p>\n<p>Apple’s impetus to keep on keeping on isn’t hard to understand. But, as the App Store embarks upon its second decade of operation, it may at least be worthwhile to investigate what changes could be made to improve it.</p><p><a href=\"https://www.macworld.com/article/3569278/time-for-apple-to-reevaluate-how-the-app-store-does-business.html\">Continue reading on Macworld</a>.</p>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 03 Aug 2020 12:31:33 +0000","feedId":1506,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"36246dfd5feccac66f2d1147c8b252d8","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"Dan Moren","publishedOrCreatedDate":1598293144141},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 02:19:04","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 02:19:04","title":"(Podcast) The Rebound #300: 300","link":"https://sixcolors.com/?p=12417","description":"<p>It’s The Rebound 300th Episode Extravaganza and we’ve got guests, songs, dancing and… </p>\n<p>I’m sorry, I’m being told it’s just guests. Still, though, that’s something.</p><p><a href=\"http://reboundcast.com/episode/300\">Go to the podcast page</a>.</p>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Wed, 29 Jul 2020 18:36:28 +0000","feedId":1506,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"a14733a4fe23684833e567439a410402","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"Dan Moren","publishedOrCreatedDate":1598293144144},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 02:19:04","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 02:19:04","title":"A few notes on Apple’s latest record quarter","link":"http://two.wordpress.test/post/2020/01/a_few_notes_on_apples_latest_record_quarter/","description":"<p>So, another record fiscal quarter for Apple. Are we surprised? Not really, I suppose, though it’s interesting to remember that last year’s holiday quarter was actually <em>smaller</em> than the previous year’s, which set the record. 2019 is now the champ, with $91.8 billion in revenue. Yikes.</p>\n<p>Anyway, here are a few quick observations about this quarter’s Best Quarter Ever.</p>\n<h2>The iPhone 11 is the core iPhone</h2>\n<p>If you were wondering about Apple’s strategy to make the successor to the iPhone XR the “real” iPhone 11, and rebranding the iPhone X successors as pro models, wonder no more. According to Apple, the iPhone 11 outsold the iPhone 11 Pro and 11 Pro Max every single week of the holiday quarter.</p>\n<p>That said, I’d assume that the two pro models put together outsold the iPhone 11. But it’s clear that the iPhone 11 has been a success, and it’s only right.</p>\n<p>Also, let’s give a clap to the iPhone, which returned to year-over-year revenue growth for the first time in a year. Apple says that its trade-in programs have worked wonders, including in China. and also suggests that the (U.S. only) Apple Card installment plan also has helped contribute to iPhone sales.</p>\n<p>The iPhone is never going to be the growth engine it was during the middle of the last decade, but it’s still an enormous contributor of revenue and profit to Apple, and I suspect its sales will ebb and flow as new models come and go. There are worse things for a company to have than a boring product that just keeps dumping $146 billion a year into the coffers.</p>\n<figure><img src=\"https://i0.wp.com/sixcolors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/financials-2020-1-2-1.png?ssl=1\" alt=\"iPhone revenue chart\" data-image-w=\"\" data-image-h=\"\" class=\" jetpack-broken-image\" data-recalc-dims=\"1\"></figure><h2>Wearables are big—and interesting</h2>\n<p>Apple’s wearables business is clearly successful and growing rapidly, as expressed in the Wearable/Home/Accessories category’s rapid growth. It was $10 billion in revenue for that category this quarter, up 37 percent from the year-ago quarter and marking 12 straight quarters of 20+% growth.</p>\n<p>Apple provided a few fun tidbits in its description of what’s going on inside the Wearable/Home/Accessories bundle. Apple Watch set a new revenue record, though Apple won’t say what that record is. Perhaps more interesting even than that, the company claimed that 75 percent of Apple Watch purchases were from people who were new to the product.</p>\n<figure><img src=\"https://i1.wp.com/sixcolors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/financials-2020-1-3-1.png?ssl=1\" alt=\"Wearables revenue chart\" data-image-w=\"\" data-image-h=\"\" class=\" jetpack-broken-image\" data-recalc-dims=\"1\"><p>On the <a href=\"https://sixcolors.com/post/2020/01/this-is-tim-apple-q1-2020-results-transcript/\">phone call with analysts and executives</a> Tuesday, Mike Olson of Piper Sandler<sup id=\"fnref-4079-sandler\"><a href=\"https://sixcolors.com#fn-4079-sandler\" class=\"jetpack-footnote\">1</a></sup> asked Cook about how many of those watch buyers were really new to Apple overall. Cook’s response was that “it’s more likely that the iPhone comes first,” which is probably true—first you get an iPhone, then you branch out into the Watch. (Keep in mind, you can’t really use an Apple Watch <em>without</em> an iPhone.) And there are so many iPhone users out there that Apple could keep adding 75 percent new Watch owners every quarter for quite a while without running out of potential sales targets.</p>\n<p>But Cook did say, “There’s no doubt in my mind that there’s some people that came into the ecosystem for the Watch,” and I can see that point too. With Apple having the pre-eminent smartwatch out there, Apple probably benefits from a surprising halo effect: Someone who might not care whether their phone is iPhone or Android might buy an iPhone just because they want to get an Apple Watch.</p>\n<p>Apple Watch sales aren’t all about the Series 5, either. Cook said that Apple couldn’t make enough of the $199/$299 Apple Watch Series 3. That’s a fascinating tidbit, because it suggests that—like the iPhone SE before it—Apple underestimated the amount of demand that its customers might have for a lower-priced, entry-level product. At $199, the Apple Watch Series 3 is priced similarly to a bunch of other fitness trackers—and it seems to have found some traction there.</p>\n<p>Then there’s the AirPods and AirPods Pro, which also achieved record revenues. According to Cook, Apple couldn’t make enough AirPods Pro to meet demand—and that’s still the case, and the company doesn’t know when it will be able to. That’s the sign of a hit product (or enormous production problems, but I’ll guess the former).</p>\n<h2>The arrow points up</h2>\n<p>If you’re not an investor or Wall Street analyst you might have missed perhaps the most important news Apple broke on Tuesday. It’s not about the 2019 calendar holiday quarter, it’s about the second fiscal quarter of 2020, the one we’re living in right now. Every quarter, Apple supplies guidance about how it thinks it will perform in the next quarter. On Tuesday it said it would generate between $63 and $67 billion, a wide spread that it said was due in part to some uncertainty about what will happen with the spread of the Coronavirus in Wuhan, China.</p>\n<p>That’s great news for Wall Street. Not only did Apple beat its own guidance for this quarter, but it’s now projecting another quarter of year-over-year growth. The fiscal second quarter of 2019 was a $58 billion quarter, so Apple’s predicting growth of between 8 and 16 percent. Until this latest quarter, Apple’s year-over-year revenue growth had been pretty static for a year, measuring between a 5 percent drop and a 2 percent rise. This guidance suggests that Apple will follow up this quarter’s 9% growth with a figure that’s similar, with quite a bit of possible upside.</p>\n<p>It’s a good sign that Apple is confident about the direction its business is going in.</p>\n<h2>What’s up with the Mac and the iPad?</h2>\n<p>Mac and iPad sales were down. The Mac was down 3% and the iPad was down 11%. A little scary, but Apple put a positive spin on it, mostly saying that this quarter was a “tough compare” to the year-ago quarter, because the product mix was very different.</p>\n<figure><img src=\"https://i2.wp.com/sixcolors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/financials-2020-1-1-4.png?ssl=1\" data-image-w=\"\" data-image-h=\"\" class=\" jetpack-broken-image\" data-recalc-dims=\"1\"></figure><figure><img src=\"https://i0.wp.com/sixcolors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/financials-2020-1-1-1.png?ssl=1\" data-image-w=\"\" data-image-h=\"\" class=\" jetpack-broken-image\" data-recalc-dims=\"1\"></figure><p>“Both products had a difficult year-over-year comparison due to the launches of MacBook Air, Mac Mini, and iPad Pro during the December quarter a year ago,” Maestri said. And he’s got a point. There was no major iPad release this year during that period, and that definitely made this year’s holiday quarter pale in comparison to last year’s.</p>\n<p>I do think it’s interesting that Apple pointed to the “tough compare” argument for the Mac, though. A new 16-inch MacBook Pro presumably had some impact on sales, though the Mac Pro wouldn’t have—not only did it ship at the very end of the quarter, but it’s not the kind of high-volume product that has a heavy impact on the bottom line. There was a lot of pent-up demand for the MacBook Pro, sure, but a lot of people are probably waiting and hoping for a revision to the smaller MacBook Pro model, and there was an <em>enormous</em> amount of pent-up demand for the MacBook Air last year.</p>\n<p>We’ll see whether the Mac and the iPad can turn it around when we check back in on Apple’s financial results in three months. Set your calendar alarms for April 28.</p>\n<div class=\"footnotes\">\n<hr><ol><li id=\"fn-4079-sandler\">\nOh no, did Adam Sandler kill Mr. Jaffray and steal his power? <a href=\"https://sixcolors.com#fnref-4079-sandler\"><img src=\"https://s.w.org/images/core/emoji/13.0.0/72x72/21a9.png\" alt=\"↩\" class=\"wp-smiley\" style=\"height: 1em; As we roll into the ’20s, Apple has positioned itself at the forefront of a bunch of different technological niches, but one place that it seems to be putting an especial amount of attention in the year ahead is smart home technology.</p>\n<p>Apple’s no newbie to the market, of course. HomeKit, the company’s smart home framework, has been around since 2014, and though it was slow to take off, a few key changes have helped it become more popular as the years have gone on.</p>\n<p>That said, there’s a lot of competition in the smart home arena, which can mean extra complications when the field is growing so fast: fragmentation, problems with interoperability, and so on. The MacBook Air, which Apple dubs “the world’s most loved notebook”<sup id=\"fnref-10833-mostloved\"><a href=\"https://sixcolors.com#fn-10833-mostloved\" class=\"jetpack-footnote\">1</a></sup> has received a notable boost today, with not only the new Magic Keyboard, but improved storage, and a better processor line-up.</p>\n<p>The Magic Keyboard is the same found in the new 16-inch MacBook Pro, with improved key travel, a scissor mechanism, and, as Apple says, “the new inverted-“T” arrangement for the arrow keys makes them easier to find without looking down.”<sup id=\"fnref-10833-new\"><a href=\"https://sixcolors.com#fn-10833-new\" class=\"jetpack-footnote\">2</a></sup> (These people get me.)</p>\n<p>The 10th-generation Intel Core processors featured in the new MacBooks mark the first time quad-core chips have appeared in the product, and they range from a Core i3 at 1.1GHz to a 1.2GHz Core i7 with Turbo Boost up to 3.8GHz, making them twice as fast as the previous generation of MacBook Air. They also include Intel Iris Plus Graphics, which Apple says boosts the notebook’s graphics performance by 80 percent, and now allows the Air to drive an external 6K display.</p>\n<p>Storage has also been doubled for the standard configurations, starting at a very reasonable 256GB for the base Core i3 model at that ever-desirable $999 price point ($899 for educational buyers); a $1299 model sports a Core i5 and 512GB of storage. Customization options on both models include doubling the RAM from the standard 8GB to 16GB for $200, and 1TB or 2TB of storage, the price of which varies depending on the model. A 1.2GHz Core i7 processor is also available as a build-to-order option.</p>\n<p>Apple has also included Bluetooth 5.0, as well as beefing up the sound system, which now includes support for Dolby Atmos playback, and a three-mic array with directional beam forming, features that debuted on the 16-inch MacBook Pro last year.</p>\n<p>A side-by-side comparison with the previous model also notes that Apple has reduced its battery life estimates on the new models, which are now only rated for 11 hours of wireless web and 12 hours of Apple TV app movie playback, down from 12 and 13 respectively. It’s also slightly heavier than its predecessor: 2.8 pounds instead of 2.75.</p>\n<p>All in all, it’s a traditional Apple update: better things in the same package, at an equivalent or lower price point. Hard to argue with that.</p>\n<p>Oh, and Apple also took the time to say that it had boosted Mac mini storage configurations: the $799 model comes with a 256GB SSD, while the $1099 model starts at 512GB. Last week, Apple announced the schedule for the event, confirming that it will kick off with the traditional keynote on Monday, June 22nd.</p>\n<p>So. Start your engines and let the speculation begin. What exactly will Apple be discussing in said keynote? Which announcements will they make? What rumors will immediately dissipate into dust?</p>\n<p>Of course, my Magic 8-Ball is only as good as any you can get from a toy store, so I can’t tell you exactly what Apple’s going to show off. But what I can tell you is what I want to see from the company. Here are a few of the things that I’m the most excited to hear about when Tim Cook steps into a virtual keynote in just seven short days.</p><p><a href=\"https://www.macworld.com/article/3562573/wwdc-2020-hopes-and-dreams-for-ios-macs-and-more.html\">Continue reading on Macworld</a>.</p>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 15 Jun 2020 11:54:01 +0000","feedId":1506,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"d945f31b379264820a8725014a47523c","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"Dan Moren","publishedOrCreatedDate":1598293144219},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 02:19:04","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 02:19:04","title":"(Podcast) 20 Macs for 2020: Power Mac G5 (#20)","link":"https://sixcolors.com/?p=12669","description":"<p>The classic “cheese grater” design of the Power Mac G5 influences the design of the modern Mac Pro, and also represents (in the worst way) the last time Apple embarked on a chip transition.</p><p><a href=\"https://www.relay.fm/20macs/1\">Go to the podcast page</a>.</p>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 07 Aug 2020 16:03:05 +0000","feedId":1506,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"4cb61fc529a02cac6e1b4a96e857c65f","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"Jason Snell","enclosureType":"audio/mpeg","enclosureUrl":"https://www.podtrac.com/pts/redirect.mp3/theincomparable.com/podcast/20macs-20-power-mac-g5-xyz.mp3","publishedOrCreatedDate":1598293144127},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 02:19:04","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 02:19:04","title":"20 Macs for 2020: An Introduction","link":"https://sixcolors.com/?p=12427","description":"<figure class=\"pull-right\"><img src=\"https://i0.wp.com/sixcolors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/20macstitle.png?ssl=1\" alt=\"20 Macs for 2020\" data-image-w=\"\" data-image-h=\"\" class=\" jetpack-broken-image\" data-recalc-dims=\"1\"></figure><p>I’ve been a professional observer of the Mac for three-quarters of its life. Sticking around that long—27 years—has given me a deeper perspective on its history. I remember the Mac before OS X, before the iMac, before PowerPC, even before System 7. We go way back.</p>\n<p>With this year marking the turn of decades (in some particularly disastrous ways, as it turns out), I decided to construct a list of the 20 most notable Macs in history. Over the next 20 weeks, I’ll post essays, podcasts, and videos about each of them, counting down to number one.</p>\n<p>Now, note my choice of words there: <em>notable</em>. I’m not saying these are my favorite Macs—a bunch of them I only knew in passing and never used myself. I’m not saying these are the best Macs ever—a difficult thing to measure, since (with a few obvious exceptions) the best Macs made are the most recent ones, otherwise we’d all still be using G3 iMacs.</p>\n<p>My ranking system is, to be blunt, arbitrary. I tried to make a list of notable Macs that I felt reflected Mac history over the last 36 years. I wanted to choose Macs that were popular, revolutionary, weird, or had an interesting story to tell. If I have learned anything from Joe Posnanski’s brilliant <a href=\"https://theathletic.com/tag/the-baseball-100/\">Baseball 100 project</a>, one of the most popular things about this series will be arguments about my terrible rankings and my unforgivable omissions.</p>\n<p>To this, I can only say: My rankings may be terrible, and my omissions unforgivable, but they’re mine. Play along, make your own list, post it to the Internet, and see if everyone agrees.</p>\n<p>Or as Posnanski put it, “The point of this for me is not the ranking but the stories.”</p>\n<p>To take this walk down memory lane, I’ve read through many back issues of Macworld, MacUser, and MacWEEK, picked up a few books, and talked to some of my distinguished Mac journalism colleagues. I appreciate their contributions to the project.</p>\n<p>Beyond the arguments about list-making, I hope the results of this project will expose some Mac history that deserves to be brought back into the light while entertaining along the way.</p>\n<p>In addition to my <a href=\"https://sixcolors.com/20macs\">weekly essays here at Six Colors</a>, there will be an <a href=\"https://relay.fm/20macs\">accompanying podcast</a> at Relay FM, and a video series (made in collaboration with Stephen Hackett) on <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCZzXBTOSdtmOz9_VMYffr4g\">the 512 Pixels YouTube channel</a>.</p>\n<p>Let’s get started.</p>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 03 Aug 2020 15:50:36 +0000","feedId":1506,"bgimg":"https://i0.wp.com/sixcolors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/20macstitle.png?ssl=1","linkMd5":"4ab8707c1802d333b6d59121107f52e1","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn87@2020_1/2020/08/24/18-19-09-405_182461b8798cc0e1.webp","destWidth":680,"destHeight":213,"sourceBytes":19980,"destBytes":19980,"author":"Jason Snell","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i0.wp.com/sixcolors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/20macstitle.png?ssl=1":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn87@2020_1/2020/08/24/18-19-09-405_182461b8798cc0e1.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598293144141},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 02:19:04","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 02:19:04","title":"Star Wars: Squadrons preps for launch ↦","link":"https://sixcolors.com/?p=11338","description":"<p>I’ve been beating the drum for a Star Wars dogfighting game in the style of the classic <em>X-Wing</em> and <em>TIE Fighter</em> games for as long as I can remember, and it looks like it may have finally paid off.</p>\n<figure class=\"youtube\"><p><iframe width=\"560\" height=\"315\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/w0eRkhR1z6A\" frameborder=\"0\" allow=\"accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture\" allowfullscreen></iframe></p>\n</figure><p>EA on Monday took the wraps off its upcoming game, <em>Star Wars: Squadrons</em>, with <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=w0eRkhR1z6A&#38;feature=youtu.be\">a cinematic trailer</a>. More details are expected later this week at the <a href=\"https://www.ea.com/ea-play-live\">EA Play Live</a> event, but here’s what we do know <a href=\"https://www.theverge.com/21289266/star-wars-squadrons-game-trailer-multiplayer-team-x-wing\">via The Verge</a>: the game has both five-on-five multiplayer as well as a single-player campaign set at the end of the Galactic Civil War (read: the original trilogy). There will also be other modes, including “Fleet Battles” where you team up with you squadron mates to take down a bigger ship, like a Star Destroyer.</p>\n<p><em>Squadrons</em> debuts on October 2nd for $40, and will be available for Xbox One, PlayStation 4, and PC, with cross-platform play enabled. Both the PS4 and PC versions will also feature VR support.</p>\n<p>Having been anticipating this for years now, fall can’t come soon enough for me. Here’s hoping that additional details from EA only whet the appetite more.</p><p><a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=w0eRkhR1z6A&#038;feature=youtu.be\">Go to the linked site</a>.</p><p><a href=\"https://sixcolors.com/link/2020/06/star-wars-squadrons-preps-for-launch/\">Read on Six Colors</a>.</p>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 15 Jun 2020 17:23:38 +0000","feedId":1506,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"51d3a1dc8e6c3947d6b39bed15115eb5","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"Dan Moren","publishedOrCreatedDate":1598293144219},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 02:19:04","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 02:19:04","title":"20 Macs for 2020: #20 – Power Mac G5","link":"https://sixcolors.com/?p=12429","description":"<p>After Steve Jobs returned to Apple in the late ’90s, he famously simplified the company’s product line by drawing a four-product grid: consumer desktop (the bulbous, brightly colored G3 iMac), consumer laptop (then, just an empty space), professional desktop (the Power Mac, first the blue-and-white G3 and then the G4), and professional laptop (the PowerBook).</p>\n<p><span id=\"more-12429\"></span></p>\n<figure class=\"pull-right\"><img src=\"https://i2.wp.com/mt.sixcolors.com/images/content/2020/power-mac-g5-6c.jpg?ssl=1\" alt=\"power-mac-g5\" data-image-w=\"\" data-image-h=\"\" class=\" jetpack-broken-image\" data-recalc-dims=\"1\"><figcaption></figcaption></figure><p>There was no consumer laptop in Apple’s product line until the iBook was announced. PowerBooks were <em>expensive</em>. And as for that consumer desktop, the G3 iMac was a wild success<sup id=\"fnref-12429-imac\"><a href=\"https://sixcolors.com#fn-12429-imac\" class=\"jetpack-footnote\">1</a></sup>, but for years the <em>real</em> Mac users looked down on it as a weird, underpowered toy that wasn’t suited for getting real work done<sup id=\"fnref-12429-work\"><a href=\"https://sixcolors.com#fn-12429-work\" class=\"jetpack-footnote\">2</a></sup>.</p>\n<p>In this context, it’s easy to underestimate just how much importance the professional Mac tower had in the mind of the Mac world back in the day.  As defined by the standards of the 90s and early 2000s, these were <em>real</em> computers—boxes you could open up and swap hard drives, install RAM, stick in expansion cards, maybe even upgrade the processor itself. Time and trends and Apple’s own predilections have led us to a world, two decades later, where the only Mac that fits these criteria starts at $6,000, but back then the desktop tower was <em>the</em> Mac. The one that mattered.<sup id=\"fnref-12429-garbage\"><a href=\"https://sixcolors.com#fn-12429-garbage\" class=\"jetpack-footnote\">3</a></sup></p>\n<p>In the summer of 2003, Apple introduced an entirely new Mac tower, one that traded the cute colorful plastic of the Power Mac G3 and the more subdued gray and silver plastic of the Power Mac G4 for a more serious industrial design, clad in aluminum. In the early 2000s, colorful computers were for consumers and monochrome computers were for <em>serious</em> computer users.<sup id=\"fnref-12429-gray\"><a href=\"https://sixcolors.com#fn-12429-gray\" class=\"jetpack-footnote\">4</a></sup></p>\n<p>The <a href=\"https://everymac.com/systems/apple/powermac_g5/specs/powermac_g5_1.8.html\">Power Mac G5</a> design represented the high-end Mac tower for a decade, keeping its distinctive look outside while adapting and changing on the inside. It survived the Intel transition. The G5 design, with a front panel punched so full of holes that it was 65 percent aluminum and 35 percent air, was so logical for a computer packed full of hot, high-powered components that after a six year hiatus, Apple brought back a Mac Pro that is deeply inspired by the design of the original. Like its predecessor, the 2019 Mac Pro also looks like nothing more than a giant box grater.</p>\n<h2>An executive briefing</h2>\n<figure class=\"pull-right\"><img src=\"https://i1.wp.com/mt.sixcolors.com/images/content/2020/power-mac-g5-cover-6c.jpg?ssl=1\" alt=\"power-mac-g5-cover\" data-image-w=\"\" data-image-h=\"\" class=\" jetpack-broken-image\" data-recalc-dims=\"1\"><figcaption></figcaption></figure><p>The Power Mac G5 <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iwsn27J_tlo\">was announced at WWDC in 2003</a> as “the world’s fastest personal computer.” Steve Jobs pointed out it was also the first 64-bit processor in a desktop computer, proudly trumpeting Apple’s partnership with IBM to create the G5 processor, which was replacing the Motorola-built PowerPC G4 at the top of Apple’s product line.</p>\n<p>Apple was proud of the hardware design, so proud that I managed to score a hands-on briefing where I could walk through the design decisions with Apple execs for a cover story in Macworld. Macworld Expo in New York was coming up, so the only time we could meet was on the afternoon of July 3, the day before the long Independence Day weekend.</p>\n<p>My wife and our one-year-old daughter and I were driving down to L.A. for the weekend, so we ended up stopping at Infinite Loop on the way south. A very nice Apple P.R. person (I wish I could remember who she was!) took them to the Company Store while I went into the executive briefing center. My daughter ended up with a new Apple onesie out of the deal.</p>\n<p>The briefing was one for the books. Greg Jozwiak—who still frequently takes to the stage at Apple events—represented product marketing and Jon Rubinstein, Apple’s SVP of hardware engineering was there for the engineering side. For an hour, we stood around an opened-up G5 and walked through every little corner of that tower, as they told story after story about why particular design decisions had been made.</p>\n<p>Today, that would be a podcast interview, and maybe a YouTube video. Back then, it generated three pages of photos showing both sides of the G5 motherboard, the inside of the case, and the front and back of the computer’s exterior, complete with quotes from both of them. It was an unusual way to do that story, right down to my insistence that we quote them at length and refer to them by their nicknames, Joz and Ruby.</p>\n<figure><img src=\"https://i0.wp.com/mt.sixcolors.com/images/content/2020/power-mac-g5-spread-6c.jpg?ssl=1\" alt=\"\" data-image-w=\"\" data-image-h=\"\" class=\" jetpack-broken-image\" data-recalc-dims=\"1\"><figcaption></figcaption></figure><p>With 17 years of hindsight, the thing that sticks out the most about the G5’s design is just how obsessed it was about moving air around. Consider the two pro Macs that bracket this design: the previous tower, the final Power Mac G4, was nicknamed the “wind tunnel” because of its loud, aggressive fan noise. The 2013 Mac Pro, on the other hand, famously failed because it couldn’t keep its components cool enough, leading Apple into a “<a href=\"https://daringfireball.net/2017/04/the_mac_pro_lives\">thermal corner</a>” from which it couldn’t escape.</p>\n<p>The G5 was all about moving air around intelligently and quietly. In the WWDC keynote, Steve Jobs boasts about how it’s got nine fans, but you won’t hear them because they’re all individually computer controlled. If you took off the metal door on the outside of the G5, you’d be prompted by a clear plastic <em>second</em> door, this one there to keep the entire thermal container sealed. The power supply, processors, PCI cards, and storage bay were all separate air zones, moving from front to back.</p>\n<p>Over the years, the airflow design on the inside changed as components changed, but the premise remained the same: Keep moving air through this thing so it can keep doing its job. It’s something the 2019 Mac Pro does, too. It’s a lesson learned from the Power Mac G5.</p>\n<h2>Bunny suits and betrayal</h2>\n<figure><img src=\"https://i0.wp.com/mt.sixcolors.com/images/content/2020/DSC01932-6c.jpg?ssl=1\" alt=\"\" data-image-w=\"\" data-image-h=\"\" class=\" jetpack-broken-image\" data-recalc-dims=\"1\"><figcaption>Photo by Stephen Hackett.</figcaption></figure><p>Don’t make Steve Jobs look like a fool. You will regret it.</p>\n<p>Given the <a href=\"https://mt.sixcolors.com/images/content/2020/steve-jobs-ibm-2-6c.jpg\">history between Jobs and IBM</a>, it’s quite a thing to consider just how much praise Jobs and Apple lavished on IBM during the launch of the Power Mac G5.</p>\n<p>The truth is, when Jobs returned to Apple he found the company in a vulnerable position when it came to Mac processors. The PowerPC chip architecture used in every Mac was a constant sore spot. It’s not quite fair to say Macs were always slower than comparable PCs running Intel processors, but they frequently were—and even when they weren’t, they often lagged behind in sheer clock speed. Try explaining to someone that a 1.5GHz Motorola G4 processor is actually faster than a 1.7 GHz Intel processor—either they won’t believe you because one number is larger than the other, or their eyes will just glaze over in boredom. (It happened on stage at Macworld Expo New York once. True story.)</p>\n<p>Here’s what I wrote back in 2003:</p>\n<blockquote><p>\n  Anyone who’s paid attention to the competitive world of desktop computers has noticed that as PC chip makers Intel and AMD have accelerated their chips to incredibly high clock speeds, the G4 has lagged behind. Lately, even Apple seemed to stop protesting that the gap was purely mathematical and not real.\n</p></blockquote>\n<p>Apple ended up hitching the future of Mac chip development to IBM, its other PowerPC alliance partner. IBM had been focusing on high-end workstation processors, and that seemed like a good fit for the Power Mac line, at least. Then Apple went to work doing its marketing thing, with that IBM relationship at the center. Steve Jobs held up a polished silicon wafer and showed photos of the IBM factory in Fishkill, New York, where the G5 was being made.</p>\n<p>If anyone remembers Macworld Expo New York 2003, it’s as the last hurrah of the show in New York before it crept back to Boston to die. Jobs didn’t even appear, but there was still an Apple “opening feature presentation” (presented by Greg Joswiak) and a hefty Apple presence. I remember it differently, mostly because I was part of a group of journalists who took a field trip upstate to Fishkill to see the IBM factory. We put on white bunny suits and wandered through a series of clean rooms where robots created IBM’s cutting-edge processors, including the G5.</p>\n<p>What a world! I’d written about Apple for a decade, only to suddenly find myself in an IBM factory. It wasn’t quite Microsoft HQ, but it still felt like being in the belly of the beast. But this was a new world. IBM and its chip-making prowess was now the savior of the Mac. A big, beautiful G5 future was ahead.</p>\n<p>So, about that…</p>\n<p>In hindsight, it’s clear that Steve Jobs placed a trust in IBM that it simply didn’t merit. I have to believe Jobs thought IBM could deliver 3GHz G5 chips within 12 months. (The G5’s fastest chip at launch was a dual 2GHz model—meanwhile, Intel was already selling 3GHz chips.) It was “a guarantee the likes of which Apple had never before offered,” as I wrote back then. Jobs seemed confident, IBM seemed confident, and they sold that confidence.</p>\n<p>Apple shipped Macs with G5 processors for three years. There was <em>never</em> a 3GHz G5 chip. While there eventually was a G5 iMac, there was <em>never</em> a G5 laptop. The architecture wasn’t ever conducive to being used on mobile devices. Steve Jobs accepted an IBM projection, made a promise, hyped its relationship with IBM…and got burned.</p>\n<p>Here’s what happened next: Apple revved up a secret project to ensure that Mac OS X could compile for Intel processors. Less than two years after members of the media frolicked in bunny suits in Fishkill, Apple announced that it was dumping the PowerPC entirely and moving to Intel.  A couple of years later, Apple finally reached 3GHz with a Mac tower and it was a Mac Pro powered by an Intel Xeon processor.</p>\n<p>Also in the background, Apple had begun talking to other chip design companies about alternatives to the G5, desperately trying to find a new chip to power its laptops. One of those companies was P.A. Semi, which Apple ended up buying outright in 2008. P.A. Semi’s engineering team became Apple’s chipmaking team.</p>\n<p>This is perhaps the ultimate lesson of the entire G5 affair: Steve Jobs, and through him Apple’s larger corporate culture, was reminded that if you are reliant on a partner for a crucial portion of your business, you can’t truly control that business. Making the G5 was a side hustle of a side hustle of a company in transformation—it just wasn’t that important to IBM, but it was vitally important for Apple.</p>\n<p>Jobs and Apple learned their lesson. The acquisition of P.A. Semi led to the A series of processors that run the iPhone and iPad. They are widely considered to be superior to the processors used by Apple’s competition. And now Apple has picked up stakes once again and plans to make Macs powered by new versions of those processors.</p>\n<p>You could argue that the Power Mac G5 has IBM’s failure inscribed in its very name. But I prefer to consider the aluminum cheese-grater design as a classic that bridged the gap between IBM and Intel. It was a design too good to throw away, and after a brief blip, it’s still with us today—albeit in a modernized form with more stainless steel and weirder holes.</p>\n<figure class=\"youtube\"><p><iframe width=\"560\" height=\"315\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/P_y9Fi3uGu4\" frameborder=\"0\" allow=\"accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture\" allowfullscreen></iframe></p>\n</figure><p>I’ll be back next week with number 19.</p>\n<div class=\"footnotes\">\n<hr><ol><li id=\"fn-12429-imac\">\nBut that’s another article. <a href=\"https://sixcolors.com#fnref-12429-imac\"><img src=\"https://s.w.org/images/core/emoji/13.0.0/72x72/21a9.png\" alt=\"↩\" class=\"wp-smiley\" style=\"height: 1em; max-height: 1em;\" /></a>\n</li>\n<li id=\"fn-12429-work\">\nApple kept iterating on the iMac, and with every turn of the wheel it got better. Today I’d wager that very few Mac users do work that couldn’t be handled ably by an iMac. <a href=\"https://sixcolors.com#fnref-12429-work\"><img src=\"https://s.w.org/images/core/emoji/13.0.0/72x72/21a9.png\" alt=\"↩\" class=\"wp-smiley\" style=\"height: 1em; max-height: 1em;\" /></a>\n</li>\n<li id=\"fn-12429-garbage\">\nLaptops in this era were really slow. Hug your modern MacBook Pro and whisper words of thanks in its air vent. <a href=\"https://sixcolors.com#fnref-12429-garbage\"><img src=\"https://s.w.org/images/core/emoji/13.0.0/72x72/21a9.png\" alt=\"↩\" class=\"wp-smiley\" style=\"height: 1em; max-height: 1em;\" /></a>\n</li>\n<li id=\"fn-12429-gray\">\nLooking at today’s gray-metal Macs makes me wonder if the computer design pendulum will ever swing back to glossy and colorful. I’d love to see a shiny, colorful laptop in the vein of the iPhone 11. <a href=\"https://sixcolors.com#fnref-12429-gray\"><img src=\"https://s.w.org/images/core/emoji/13.0.0/72x72/21a9.png\" alt=\"↩\" class=\"wp-smiley\" style=\"height: 1em; max-height: 1em;\" /></a>\n</li>\n</ol></div>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 03 Aug 2020 16:00:42 +0000","feedId":1506,"bgimg":"https://i2.wp.com/mt.sixcolors.com/images/content/2020/power-mac-g5-6c.jpg?ssl=1","linkMd5":"a21eda1f81cab898a55acbae88a688ce","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn59@2020_6/2020/08/24/18-19-06-538_9313c72788ca0c1e.webp","destWidth":680,"destHeight":813,"sourceBytes":72194,"destBytes":72194,"author":"Jason Snell","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i2.wp.com/mt.sixcolors.com/images/content/2020/power-mac-g5-6c.jpg?ssl=1":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn59@2020_6/2020/08/24/18-19-06-538_9313c72788ca0c1e.webp","https://i1.wp.com/mt.sixcolors.com/images/content/2020/power-mac-g5-cover-6c.jpg?ssl=1":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn78@2020_3/2020/08/24/18-19-20-937_3778a366983d76e7.webp","https://i0.wp.com/mt.sixcolors.com/images/content/2020/power-mac-g5-spread-6c.jpg?ssl=1":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn72@2020_4/2020/08/24/18-19-16-205_24c8478ab9788971.webp","https://i0.wp.com/mt.sixcolors.com/images/content/2020/DSC01932-6c.jpg?ssl=1":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn16@2020_4/2020/08/24/18-19-12-334_58b61bb86f1b6c23.webp","https://s.w.org/images/core/emoji/13.0.0/72x72/21a9.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn51@2020_2/2020/08/24/18-19-11-215_25686225908fe44d.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598293144172},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 02:19:04","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 02:19:04","title":"The Back Page: Patently obvious (Member Post)","link":"https://sixcolors.com/?p=12309","description":"<p>Notoriously secret as Apple is, there are but a limited number of ways to discover what exactly the company is developing. Thanks to our current ongoing pandemic, my surefire proprietary method—rooting through the compost bins, discarded smoothie containers, and perfectly round pizza boxes in Apple Park’s industrial trash compactors—has become impractical.</p>\n<p>So I’m left instead with virtual trawling—which smells a lot better, at least. And there’s no better source for divining exactly what Apple is working on than the patent documents that it publicly files with a government agency. (I mean, we all tell the government exactly what we’re up to, no fibbing, right?)</p>\n<p>I can see the skepticism in your eyes, so allow me to banish it to another plane of existence forthwith by running down three recent inventions that the company is—and I can’t stress this highly enough—<em>definitely</em> developing. You be the judge.</p>\n<p><span id=\"more-12309\"></span></p>\n<h2>MultiPad</h2>\n<p>Your house is littered with the iPads of Days Past, and no doubt you wish you could put them to better use. Buying a MacBook Air or 13-inch MacBook Pro will get you a trackpad and keyboard, but not a <em>good</em> keyboard.</p>\n<p>Still, it can be informative. Using Geekbench 5 and list prices, here’s a view into the relative price/performance characteristics of Apple’s mobile products (and a couple of reference products from other companies):</p>\n<figure><img src=\"https://i1.wp.com/sixcolors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/geekbench-2020-price-performance-6c.png?ssl=1\" alt=\"\" data-image-w=\"\" data-image-h=\"\" class=\" jetpack-broken-image\" data-recalc-dims=\"1\"><figcaption></figcaption></figure><p>In general, the farther the dot is away from the trend line (that gray diagonal line in the center), the more impressive its performance per dollar. In a preview story on the Athletic (subscription required), reporter Daniel Kaplan <a href=\"https://theathletic.com/1568723/2020/01/29/roger-goodells-annual-super-bowl-address-takes-place-as-nfl-pushes-hard-for-a-new-labor-deal-now/\">mentioned Apple prominently</a>:</p>\n<blockquote><p>\n  The NFL under terms of its agreement with its existing media partners cannot currently negotiate with other firms.
