Fortunately, last fall I purchased an <a href=\"https://www.evehome.com/en-us/eve-degree\">Eve Degree</a>, a little HomeKit-compatible sensor that can measure temperature and humidity. It sits on the dresser in my bedroom so I can glance over and quickly see the current temperature on its display, or look it up in the Home app.<sup id=\"fnref-12276-weather\"><a href=\"https://sixcolors.com#fn-12276-weather\" class=\"jetpack-footnote\">1</a></sup></p>\n<p>So, I put together a little shortcut that gets the current outdoor temperature and compares it, then tells me where it’s warmer.</p>\n<p>Of course, that wasn’t enough. I quickly realized I have <em>two</em> possible sources in my house, as my office has a <a href=\"https://www.philips-hue.com/en-us/p/hue-motion-sensor/046677473389\">Philips Hue Motion sensor</a> that can also measure temperature. So, I now have the temperature comparison shortcut <em>average</em> the two temperatures (which are rarely more than a degree or two apart), just so I can get a better sense of indoor temperature.</p>\n<figure class=\"pull-right\"><img src=\"https://i1.wp.com/sixcolors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/shortcuts-feels-like.jpeg?ssl=1\" alt=\"\" data-image-w=\"\" data-image-h=\"\" class=\" jetpack-broken-image\" data-recalc-dims=\"1\"><figcaption></figcaption></figure><p>All well and good. But we all know—especially those of us that live in moister climates like New England—that what the temperature <em>is</em> and what it <em>feels like</em> are two different things. And while most weather apps can provide a “feels like” temperature (also known as the heat index), my indoor temperature sensors don’t have that information.</p>\n<p>Or <em>do</em> they? How <em>is</em> the heat index calculated anyway? Well, the fine folks at the U.S.’s National Weather Service not only provide a handy <a href=\"https://www.weather.gov/epz/wxcalc_heatindex\">web-based heat index calculator</a> but are also thoughtful enough to <a href=\"https://www.weather.gov/media/epz/wxcalc/heatIndex.pdf\">publish the mathematical formula behind it</a>. All the calculation requires is the temperature and the relative humidity, both of which the Eve Degree can measure, so all <em>I</em> have to do is plug those values into the formula.</p>\n<p>Well, what’s a computer good at if not mathematical formulas? So I set out to build my own shortcut to calculate feels like temperature. In a bit of serendipity, one of the actions I needed—Calculate Expression, which lets you just throw a bunch of math into an action—was just added in iOS 14, so I composed the shortcut in the beta. It took a little work to figure out exactly how to convert the notation from the formula into a shortcut-friendly version, but after a bit of trial and error, I figured it out.</p>\n<p>And so, voila! Pass <a href=\"https://www.icloud.com/shortcuts/ae6a6142caee473ab35b9a1bdc7839bb\">this shortcut</a> temperature (in Fahrenheit) and humidity<sup id=\"fnref-12276-dictionary\"><a href=\"https://sixcolors.com#fn-12276-dictionary\" class=\"jetpack-footnote\">2</a></sup> and it’ll pass you back the “feels like” temperature. (The version there requires iOS 14, as mentioned, though some third-party apps, such as <a href=\"https://toolboxpro.app\">ToolBox Pro</a>, may offer actions that can handle the work of the Calculate Expression action.)</p>\n<p>For my purposes, I’ve wrapped it in a second shortcut that retrieves the temperature and humidity from my home sensors and formats the output to compare it to the outside temperature, but you can adapt it for whatever purposes you want.</p>\n<p>Now, if you don’t mind, it feels very hot in here, so I’m going to…uhh…<em>consults shortcut</em>…stay inside, I guess.</p>\n<div class=\"footnotes\">\n<hr><ol><li id=\"fn-12276-weather\">\nSee? Motorola’s 68K chips were losing steam, and in order to keep up with IBM PC compatibles running Intel processors, Apple got together with Motorola and IBM to define a new processor architecture, the PowerPC. In order to make this move while still supporting all of the Mac’s existing software, including its operating system, Apple needed to create an emulator for 68K instructors that would run on the PowerPC. This was a multi-year project, which was started by engineer Gary Davidian at Apple in the middle of 1990….</p>\n<p>  Davidian’s emulator served as a proof of concept that emulation of 68K code could be done without too big of a hit in software speed. This convinced managers at Apple that emulation was a workable solution for users…. In October 1991, Apple announced the PowerPC alliance with IBM and Motorola, and work began to shift Davidian’s emulator over to the PowerPC architecture. New prototype plug-in boards and then full machines were built with the new chip, whose bugs were still being worked out. It took several more years, until 1994, for the first Macs with PowerPC processors, the Power Macintosh <a href=\"https://www.computerhistory.org/collections/catalog/102647305\">6100</a>, <a href=\"https://www.computerhistory.org/collections/catalog/102647308\">7100</a>, and <a href=\"https://www.computerhistory.org/collections/catalog/102661920\">8100</a>, to be released to customers. The PowerPC would be the Mac’s CPU until 2006, when Apple replaced it with Intel’s processors.\n</p></blockquote>\n<p>The CHM article links to a couple of its oral-history interviews with Davidian. Nobody thinks about the PowerPC transition much now, but it set the bar for Mac chip transitions. Rosetta 2, coming this fall to Apple silicon Macs near you, is the inheritor of Davidian’s legacy.</p><p><a href=\"https://computerhistory.org/blog/transplanting-the-macs-central-processor-gary-davidian-and-his-68000-emulator/\">Go to the linked site</a>.</p><p><a href=\"https://sixcolors.com/link/2020/07/gary-davidian-and-his-68000-emulator/\">Read on Six Colors</a>.</p>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Thu, 16 Jul 2020 01:07:37 +0000","feedId":1506,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"b38723e04e97e4e5fe59e3ffefd39f97","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"Jason Snell","publishedOrCreatedDate":1598293144158},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 02:19:04","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 02:19:04","title":"Apple’s new emojis for 2020 ↦","link":"https://sixcolors.com/?p=12147","description":"<p>It’s that time of year again. It’s just not the same as it was two decades ago. The conference can only serve a tiny fraction of developers, and it’s so expensive to attend that it prices out a large segment of the market. One-on-one interactions are great, but they’re also inefficient.</p>\n<p>Marco and David have some good ideas backed by their own experiences as developers. I hope that these same conversations are happening right now inside Apple, and that the final result is a change that benefits all developers—not just this year, but in the future, too.</p><p><a href=\"https://www.relay.fm/radar/186\">Go to the linked site</a>.</p><p><a href=\"https://sixcolors.com/link/2020/03/under_the_radar_186_replacing_wwdc/\">Read on Six Colors</a>.</p>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Wed, 04 Mar 2020 23:51:32 +0000","feedId":1506,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"d2cc672a8854d1aa25ba4849a5ae478e","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"Jason Snell","publishedOrCreatedDate":1598293144607},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 02:19:04","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 02:19:04","title":"Watchsmith developer on watchOS 7 Wishlist ↦","link":"http://two.wordpress.test/post/2020/05/watchsmith_developer_on_watchos_7_wishlist/","description":"<p>Developer _David Smith, whose apps include not only the new Watchsmith, but also venerable standbys like Pedometer++ and Sleep++ has <a href=\"https://david-smith.org/blog/2020/05/15/opportunities-for-watchos-7/\">written up the improvements he’d like to see in watchOS 7</a> when it’s presumably announced at this year’s WWDC:</p>\n<blockquote><p>\n  I really wish the Apple Watch had some concept of a rest day. Not only is it predicated on the dumbest of Apple’s App Store rule choices—banning links to a company’s web site if there’s any way to get to a page that might possibly insinuate that there’s a way to give them money that isn’t via in-app purchase—but the act of approaching WordPress and recommending in-app purchases feels an awful lot like a shakedown. (“If you want to stay in the App Store, you might want to start upselling your users right within your app and giving us 30 percent,” Mullenweg might have imagined Apple saying.)</p>\n<p>Also troubling: Mullenweg only went public with Apple’s rejection because Apple had, <a href=\"https://twitter.com/photomatt/status/1297325896274030593\">weeks before</a>, told WordPress that Apple’s decision was final and that they’d need to alter their app to add in-app purchases in order to stay in the App Store. Phil Schiller?) guideline that “going to the press never helps” may be the most hilariously false thing Apple has ever produced.</p>\n<p>But let’s consider the larger issues. ↦","link":"http://two.wordpress.test/post/2020/04/like_it_or_not_cobol_keeps_on_running/","description":"<p>The venerable programming language COBOL is in the news a lot these days, after the governor of New Jersey went on live TV and explained that the state wasn’t able to process an avalanche of unemployment claims <a href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2020/04/06/new-jersey-seeks-cobol-programmers-to-fix-unemployment-system.html\">because the state was in desperate need of “cobalt” programmers</a> to shore up its ancient systems.</p>\n<p>My mother-in-law was a COBOL programmer. Twice. She took it up in the 1970s, one of many women who were looking for a career opportunity and went to technical school in order to become a computer professional. (I can’t tell you how many people I’ve run into who had a mother, mother-in-law, or grandmother who was a COBOL programmer.) Then my mother-in-law came back to it in the late ’90s when there was a desperate search for people capable of reprogramming systems to avoid the Y2K bug.<sup id=\"fnref-10884-y2k\"><a href=\"https://sixcolors.com#fn-10884-y2k\" class=\"jetpack-footnote\">1</a></sup></p>\n<p>Tech nerds love pointing and laughing at old languages like COBOL and Fortran, but I wonder if perl and python and PHP will still be running 60 years from now, with minimal maintenance?</p>\n<p>Back in 2015 my pal Glenn Fleishman found <a href=\"https://www.technologyreview.com/2015/08/06/166822/what-is-the-oldest-computer-program-still-in-use/\">the oldest computer program still in  use</a> for MIT Technology Review, and guess what:</p>\n<blockquote><p>\n  In 1958, the United States Department of Defense launched a computerized contract-management system that it dubbed Mechanization of Contract Administration Services, or MOCAS (pronounced “MOH-cass”). The system was designed to use the latest in computation and output technology to track contracts in progress and payments to vendors.</p>\n<p>  Fifty-seven years later, it’s still going…. MOCAS is written in COBOL.\n</p></blockquote>\n<p>Yes, I know it’s horrifying to think that important parts of our economy might be held together with programs that were written 50 or 60 years ago. But at the same time, they still run! Rewriting programs costs money, a lot of it. Many organizations looked at their mainframes and simply never saw the reason to spend a lot of money to replace what works. Decades passed. And here we are.</p>\n<div class=\"footnotes\">\n<hr><ol><li id=\"fn-10884-y2k\">\nFor my younger readers, a lot of 20th century programs only used two digits for years, meaning they’d break the moment the year became “00”. Tech giants aren’t just capable of playing a long game, it’s required — because it can take years for technology to be conceived of and years more for the production lines to be built to manufacture it.</p>\n<p>Every smartphone is the sum of dozens of these different technologies, not just the hardware itself but the software that makes it function. Whether it’s a new camera design or a folding screen or a microprocessor or a charging port, it takes time. As Yoda taught us, always in motion the future is — and if you’re a tech CEO or product strategist, you’re making decisions now that will affect your products a year, two years, even five years down the road. There’s a reason those people get paid the big bucks, and it’s not (just) the cost of living in Santa Clara County, California.</p>\n<p>As so often happens, this week we got a glimpse at what Apple’s been working on for its next round of software updates, thanks to a series of iOS 14 leaks and Apple Watch 6 disclosures. And if you look at the substance of those leaks closely, you can see the forest for the trees. Apple’s priorities are visible. Just look.</p><p><a href=\"https://www.tomsguide.com/opinion/what-ios-14-watchos-7-leaks-tell-us-about-apple\">Continue reading on Tom&#039;s Guide</a>.</p>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sun, 15 Mar 2020 01:34:18 +0000","feedId":1506,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"aa06770b0a6c14213bd6495b0381fe28","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"Jason Snell","publishedOrCreatedDate":1598293144600},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 02:19:04","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 02:19:04","title":"2020 MacBook Air review: No news is good news","link":"http://two.wordpress.test/post/2020/03/2020-macbook-air-review/","description":"<figure><img src=\"https://i1.wp.com/sixcolors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/air18-bleed.jpg?ssl=1\" data-image-w=\"\" data-image-h=\"\" class=\" jetpack-broken-image\" data-recalc-dims=\"1\"></figure><p>[<strong>Author’s Note</strong>: <em>I’ve updated this piece to change the chart at the conclusion of the story. I put the wrong numbers in the chart, and those numbers were wildly misleading about iPad Pro 2018 performance. I regret the error. I will update this chart with data from the 2020 iPad Pro when it’s available. -j.s.</em>]</p>\n<p>Here’s what you need to know about the 2020 MacBook Air: It’s everything that was great about the <a href=\"https://sixcolors.com/post/2018/11/macbook-air-2018-review/\">2018 MacBook Air</a>, but it’s cheaper and faster, with more customizable specs and—perhaps most importantly—the same Magic Keyboard as the <a href=\"https://sixcolors.com/post/2019/11/macbook-pro-16/\">16-inch MacBook Pro</a>.</p>\n<p>Despite the keyboard and the $1099 starting price, the MacBook Air was already <a href=\"https://sixcolors.com/post/2017/07/the-right-mac-laptop-to-buy-for-a-student/\">my go-to Mac laptop recommendation</a>. What this new model has done is eliminate almost every caveat, warning, or footnote that might have come along with that recommendation. If the MacBook Air wasn’t definitively the center of the Mac world before—and Apple says it’s been the most popular Mac model “by far”—it certainly is now.</p>\n<h2>The key upgrade</h2>\n<p>If you’ve followed along with the ongoing story of Apple’s “butterfly” keyboard design, introduced with the <a href=\"https://sixcolors.com/post/2015/04/the-new-macbook-a-reviewers-notebook/\">12-inch MacBook</a> in 2015, you know that it’s been criticized for both its typing feel and its fragility. Apple instituted a special <a href=\"https://sixcolors.com/link/2018/06/apple-announces-macbook-keyboard-service-program/\">service program</a> to deal with the repair issues.</p>\n<p>This new MacBook Air model, thankfully, does not use that keyboard design. Instead, it’s got the same design as the 16-inch MacBook Pro introduced last fall. The keys use a more traditional scissor switch and offer about a millimeter of key travel. That’s not as much as in the previous, non-Retina MacBook Air, but it’s still pretty good. (And yes, this new MacBook Air also has a proper “inverted T” layout for arrow keys, as it was in the old days, allowing you to orient more easily based on key feel.)</p>\n<p>I still prefer the feel of that older Apple keyboard, but given the choice between the keyboard on the new Air and the one from the previous generation, I’d choose this new one every time. In contrast, my wife—who uses a 2018 MacBook Air with the butterfly keyboard—tried the new keyboard and shrugged. Some people just don’t care that much about keyboards!</p>\n<p>But if you’ve been holding out for a MacBook Air with Retina display that’s got a keyboard with more travel, you can end your holdout now. It’s here.</p>\n<h2>The right price</h2>\n<p>My 2018 excitement that the MacBook Air would be revived was tempered by the butterfly keyboard (did I mention I didn’t like it?), but more than that, it was by the price: $1199 (dropped to $1099 last July). After the MacBook and 13-inch MacBook Pro failed to catch on because of their high prices, I was hoping that the MacBook Air would give Apple a solid laptop option for $999. The MacBook Air was cheaper, but it couldn’t hit that magic price. (Though in fact, it <em>has</em> been hitting it via sales at various websites over the past year. I’ve bought two of the 2018 Airs for $999. But it wasn’t the “real” price.)</p>\n<p>This 2020 MacBook Air finally sets the bar at the right place: $999. While that price will only get you a dual-core i3 processor, it’ll get you 256GB of storage, double the base storage available on the old $1099 Air. (You can also upgrade to 512GB for $200, 1TB for $400, and 2TB  for $800.)</p>\n<p>I wish Apple had hit this price two years ago, but I’m glad it’s gotten there today. $999 (and $899 for education) makes this Air a lot easier to recommend to price-conscious Mac laptop buyers. Fortunately, if you were hoping for more power than a dual-core i3, Apple has options for you, too.</p>\n<h2>Choices at last</h2>\n<p>Back in the old pre-Retina days, you could configure the MacBook Air’s processor to be much more powerful than the default. (I’ve got a 2012 MacBook Air with an i7 processor that’s only now starting to show its age.) But when the Retina MacBook Air debuted in 2018, it came with only a single processor configuration: a 1.6GHz dual-core Intel Core i5, with Turbo Boost up to 3.6GHz.</p>\n<p>The 2020 MacBook Air lets users buy a faster processor if they want—and for the first time, there are four-core options for the MacBook Air. The $999 base model is powered by a 1.1GHz dual-core Intel Core i3, with Turbo Boost up to 3.2GHz. But you can also configure a 1.1GHz quad-core Intel Core i5, with Turbo Boost up to 3.5Ghz for an additional $100, or a 1.2GHz quad-core i7 with Turbo Boost up to 3.8GHz for an extra $250. While all models use Intel’s integrated Iris Plus graphics, Apple says that graphics on these models are up to 80 percent faster than the previous model.</p>\n<p>I was only able to test the $1299 model that includes the quad-core i5 processor, so I can’t test whether the highest-end model meets Apple’s claims of speeds twice as fast as the prior model. But I was able to test the new laptop in Primate Labs’ Geekbench 5 and compare it to older Mac models. The results were encouraging, with a 32 percent improvement in single-core performance and 63 percent improvement in multi-core tests. (More cores helps.)</p>\n<p>Apple seems to have hit the $999 price point by saddling it with the two-core i3 processor, while for the old $1099 price you get the mid-range processor with four cores. I’d expect the $999 model to be roughly comparable to the old model in terms of performance, but the good news is that if you want a bit more processing power, you can pay and get it. (And yes, you can take the $999 model and simply configure up the processor to the i7 model if you want to.)</p>\n<figure><img src=\"https://i2.wp.com/sixcolors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/geekbench-air-6c.png?ssl=1\" alt=\"\" data-image-w=\"\" data-image-h=\"\" class=\" jetpack-broken-image\" data-recalc-dims=\"1\"><figcaption></figcaption></figure><h2>Worth the wait?</h2>\n<p>If there’s a hint of things to come in my test results, though, it’s the performance of the iPad Pro. This isn’t the new 2020 model that’s due out next week, either—it’s the third-generation iPad Pro that was released the same day as the first Retina MacBook Air model. The 2018 iPad Pro was faster in single-core performance and 70 percent faster in multi-core performance.</p>\n<figure><img src=\"https://i0.wp.com/sixcolors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/geekbench-air-ipad-fixed-6c.png?ssl=1\" alt=\"\" data-image-w=\"\" data-image-h=\"\" class=\" jetpack-broken-image\" data-recalc-dims=\"1\"><figcaption></figcaption></figure><p>Even if we accept that macOS and iPadOS are different beasts and that a Mac built around Apple’s own A-series processors wouldn’t necessarily score quite as high, it’s a clear sign that Apple’s state of the art iPad processor from 18 months ago is faster than the mid-range MacBook Air processor today.</p>\n<p>Though rumors abound that Apple is going to be introducing ARM Macs, there’s no telling when that might happen and what form those computers might take. How compatible will they be with older software? Will Intel apps that haven’t been recompiled for ARM run in a slow code-translation layer? Will Apple have to work out bugs that come along with the transition?</p>\n<p>If you don’t really need a new Mac laptop, maybe you should wait to see what happens with ARM. But if you’re someone who has been holding out for a new MacBook Air—and ideally one without that infamous keyboard—I wouldn’t recommend that you wait. This is the MacBook Air that you’ve been waiting for.</p>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 20 Mar 2020 12:30:00 +0000","feedId":1506,"bgimg":"https://i1.wp.com/sixcolors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/air18-bleed.jpg?ssl=1","linkMd5":"f54565b1ce43beacdc554b3d82e0d9df","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn11@2020_5/2020/08/24/18-19-07-496_ff6ad3873ecae716.webp","destWidth":2048,"destHeight":1135,"sourceBytes":199682,"destBytes":199682,"author":"Jason Snell","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i1.wp.com/sixcolors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/air18-bleed.jpg?ssl=1":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn11@2020_5/2020/08/24/18-19-07-496_ff6ad3873ecae716.webp","https://i2.wp.com/sixcolors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/geekbench-air-6c.png?ssl=1":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn64@2020_3/2020/08/24/18-19-16-981_8dbbc07a69977809.webp","https://i0.wp.com/sixcolors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/geekbench-air-ipad-fixed-6c.png?ssl=1":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn46@2020_1/2020/08/24/18-19-12-309_afaee7177a033b7e.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598293144592},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 02:19:04","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 02:19:04","title":"iPad Pro 2020 review: Small steps","link":"http://two.wordpress.test/post/2020/03/ipad-pro-2020-review/","description":"<figure><img src=\"https://i0.wp.com/sixcolors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/ipad-2020-hey-buddy-6c.jpg?ssl=1\" alt=\"\" data-image-w=\"\" data-image-h=\"\" class=\" jetpack-broken-image\" data-recalc-dims=\"1\"><figcaption></figcaption></figure><p>The 2018 iPad Pro was <a href=\"https://sixcolors.com/post/2018/11/ipad-pro-2018-review/\">a great leap forward</a>, with a stylish new design, support for a new Apple Pencil, a USB-C port, and a powerful processor that was more than a match for PC laptops. In fact, you could make the argument that the 2018 iPad Pro was so far ahead of the game that it doesn’t really need much of an update, even a year and a half later.</p>\n<p>That’s essentially the argument Apple is making with this early 2020 refresh to the iPad Pro. With a few small exceptions, these new iPad Pros aren’t substantially improved from their previous generation. Even so, they’re still faster than the mid-range MacBook Air Apple also released this week.</p>\n<p>I got to spend several days using the new iPad Pro and a Smart Keyboard Folio—alas, no Magic Keyboard—and I can definitively report that unless you’re using an augmented-reality app or taking an ultra-wide photo, it’s pretty much exactly like its predecessor.</p>\n<h2>Augmented AR</h2>\n<figure><img src=\"https://i0.wp.com/sixcolors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/ipad-2020-ar-6c.jpg?ssl=1\" alt=\"\" data-image-w=\"\" data-image-h=\"\" class=\" jetpack-broken-image\" data-recalc-dims=\"1\"><figcaption>This iPad looks great in AR, not just because of LiDAR but because it’s the only way to get the Magic Keyboard into your house before May.</figcaption></figure><p>So let’s start with the big hardware upgrade: The camera bump on the iPad Pro has expanded to a square resembling the housings found on the iPhone 11 family. In this case, the iPad Pro has gained a second camera and a new LiDAR sensor.</p>\n<p>The camera is a 10 megapixel ultra-wide, allowing you to perform some of the same tricks you’d get from an iPhone 11. But there are some puzzling omissions. There’s no portrait mode, despite the presence of two cameras and a depth sensor. You also don’t get the option to integrate images that are just outside the frame of the wide camera but within the field of view of the ultrawide, presumably because that feature requires the A13 processor found in the iPhone, and doesn’t work on the A12Z processor found in the iPad Pro. There’s also no Night Mode. Basically, the iPad Pro is a state-of-the-art Apple camera—from 2018.</p>\n<p>On the other hand, the iPad Pro’s LiDAR Scanner is pure 2020. This scanner projects infrared light onto objects as far as 15 feet away, and calculates how long it takes to bounce back. That’s all happening at the speed of light, of course, so we’re talking about nanoseconds—but it allows the sensor to build a depth map of the space around it.</p>\n<p>The result is that Apple’s built-in augmented-reality engine <em>immediately</em> detects surfaces such as floors, tabletops, and walls. I was forced to wave my other Apple devices around a scene for a little while before they understood the geometry of the room I was in, but the iPad Pro knew immediately. I could quickly place an AR model on the floor, and when I slid it to a table, it immediately (and accurately) moved it there.</p>\n<p>This precision should also aid in features Apple introduced with iOS 13, most notably people occlusion, since understanding the depth of a person’s location allows the AR engine to properly guess what should go in front of or behind that person.</p>\n<p>For existing AR apps, the new LiDAR sensor will just build a better depth map—and those apps will work better. But developers can also make additional adjustments to take advantage of the increased spatial awareness caused by the LiDAR Scanner’s depth maps.</p>\n<h2>All our yesterdays</h2>\n<p>I’d like to gin up some disappointment to toss Apple’s way for not upgrading the iPad Pro to an A13-class processor, but it’s hard to do so. The A12X found in the 2018 iPad Pros is not really showing its age, and so it’s perhaps not surprising that Apple has more or less kept it around for this revision. Perhaps there’s an awesome new iPad chip in the offing, but it’s not the A12Z, which has the same processor cores as the A12X (four high-speed cores and four power-efficient ones), but has eight GPU cores instead of seven.</p>\n<p>When I ran Geekbench 5 on the two iPads, the results were entirely what you’d expect: Identical scores on single- and multi-core tests, and a slightly elevated graphics score on the new iPad. It’s truly nothing to get too excited about.</p>\n<figure><img src=\"https://i2.wp.com/sixcolors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/ipad-pro-chart-update-6c.png?ssl=1\" alt=\"\" data-image-w=\"\" data-image-h=\"\" class=\" jetpack-broken-image\" data-recalc-dims=\"1\"><figcaption></figcaption></figure><p>If there’s any other performance to be gained on these iPads, it’s from a somewhat improved thermal system in the tablet’s internal design. A more efficient thermal design doesn’t change the fundamental speed of the processor, but the better a chip can be cooled, the longer it can run at higher speeds. This means that for extended activities that tax the processor, like a video encode, the new iPad Pro might be a bit faster than the older model.</p>\n<h2>Ghost features</h2>\n<p>Apple doesn’t talk about iPad memory, but if you recall, only the highest-end model of 2018 iPad had 6GB of RAM. This meant that it could go longer without quitting apps during multitasking, and if you pushed it hard, you could tell the difference. Reports say that the 2020 models all have 6GB of RAM, and while Apple’s keeping mum, that’s a nice upgrade if true.</p>\n<p>There are also reports that it’s got a U1 chip, the same chip that Apple introduced in the iPhone 11 and enabled Ultra Wideband technology that <em>might</em> be used in future Apple products but doesn’t do much more than enhance the AirDrop interface slightly. Again, Apple won’t talk about it, and I can report that there’s no enhanced AirDrop interface on the new iPad Pro. But that doesn’t mean there isn’t a U1 chip lurking inside, ready to be activated if Apple ever ships that much-rumored tracking tag product.</p>\n<p>Apple <em>does</em> say that the new iPad Pro has a new microphone system. Like the previous model, it has five different microphones—but these use a new architecture that’s borrowed from the same source as the 16-inch MacBook Pro. I have to be honest—I recorded some audio on both iPads and couldn’t really notice any difference.</p>\n<h2>It’s important to accessorize</h2>\n<figure><img src=\"https://i2.wp.com/sixcolors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/ipad-2020-case-6c.jpg?ssl=1\" alt=\"\" data-image-w=\"\" data-image-h=\"\" class=\" jetpack-broken-image\" data-recalc-dims=\"1\"><figcaption></figcaption></figure><p>When I was a kid, the action figures were cool but their accessories were even cooler. Those Captain Kirk and Mr. Spock action figures were more exciting when they were exploring the universe in a Barbie Winnebago. (Hey, you work with what you have.) In any event, the new iPad Pro is a small update, but there’s a lot of fun action happening on the accessory front.</p>\n<p>Perhaps most notable about all of Apple’s new accessories for the 2020 iPad Pro is that they’re also compatible with the 2018 iPad Pro. (Users of older models will notice that the camera cut-out is a bit larger than the actual camera bump on those models.) Apple could’ve mandated an update to the 2020 iPad Pro model just to get at the new accessories, but it chose not to, and I appreciate that.</p>\n<p>Of course, the big attraction is the iPad Pro Magic Keyboard, which features an adjustable hinge, USB-C charging port, floating design, backlit scissor-switch keys, and a trackpad. The trackpad announcement comes <a href=\"https://sixcolors.com/post/2020/03/the-ipad-cursor-is-here-no-wait-required/\">with a major iPadOS update</a> enabling cursor support. But Apple says the accessory itself won’t be available until May, and so all I can do is stare at pictures and wonder how it feels to type on, how stable it is in a lap, and how much it actually weighs. (Apple is not saying—and yes, I asked.)</p>\n<p>Both the Magic Keyboard <em>and</em> the Smart Keyboard Folio are dark gray, the uninspiring choice of iPad Pro accessories everywhere, but I’m excited to report that Apple has added an embossed Apple logo on their backs—and the logo is oriented like you’d see it on a MacBook, in landscape. I love it.</p>\n<p>The regular Smart Folio has the logo, too, but on that one it’s in portrait orientation, so you can’t win ’em all. But I’m still excited that Apple has expanded the color options of the Smart Folio, beyond the monochrome and a pale pink, to include two “seasonal” colors—Surf Blue and Cactus. Those gray cases are so boring. I ordered a Surf Blue Smart Folio case and look forward to giving my iPad Pro some personality—when it’s not in a keyboard case, anyway.</p>\n<h2>Familiar buying advice</h2>\n<p>For years now, reviews of the new iPhone have to go out of their way to point out that most people won’t be upgrading from the previous model of phone—but from a model two or three generations back. That’s just how the upgrade cycle rolls.</p>\n<p>This is that kind of iPad Pro update. If you’ve been thinking about getting an iPad Pro, or if you’ve been using one of the first- or second-generation iPad Pro models, this product was made for you. But if you’re using a 2018 iPad Pro, you can give this iPad a pass. The difference between your 2018 model and today’s 2020 version are relatively minor, so unless you care about AR or having an ultrawide camera, you can hang tight for the <em>next</em> generation of iPad Pro.</p>\n<p>The good news is, even if you don’t upgrade, you’ll still get to take advantage of all of those new accessories for the new iPad Pro. And really, that Magic Keyboard for iPad Pro is going to be what we remember the most about this new iPad Pro. Unfortunately, that story won’t be complete until that accessory arrives on the scene in a few months. With any luck, our patience will be rewarded.</p>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Tue, 24 Mar 2020 12:30:00 +0000","feedId":1506,"bgimg":"https://i0.wp.com/sixcolors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/ipad-2020-hey-buddy-6c.jpg?ssl=1","linkMd5":"014dbbfb2e61a15a7e51889288bb68b1","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn84@2020_2/2020/08/24/18-19-09-365_d935da9904e3dc25.webp","destWidth":1360,"destHeight":793,"sourceBytes":63480,"destBytes":63480,"author":"Jason Snell","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i0.wp.com/sixcolors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/ipad-2020-hey-buddy-6c.jpg?ssl=1":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn84@2020_2/2020/08/24/18-19-09-365_d935da9904e3dc25.webp","https://i0.wp.com/sixcolors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/ipad-2020-ar-6c.jpg?ssl=1":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn67@2020_6/2020/08/24/18-19-15-369_71459f43cb13aef0.webp","https://i2.wp.com/sixcolors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/ipad-pro-chart-update-6c.png?ssl=1":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn39@2020_3/2020/08/24/18-19-16-853_8bea6cbd1f568850.webp","https://i2.wp.com/sixcolors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/ipad-2020-case-6c.jpg?ssl=1":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn71@2020_3/2020/08/24/18-19-13-139_efd806c10ec279cd.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598293144605},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 02:19:04","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 02:19:04","title":"Fun With Charts: Entirely speculative charts about Apple Silicon","link":"https://sixcolors.com/?p=12254","description":"<p>Last week I stared directly into the Apple marketing content and <a href=\"https://sixcolors.com/post/2020/07/fun-with-charts-apple-silicon-edition/\">speculated about the information it was trying to impart with a WWDC slide</a>. This week, prompted by reader David Hovis, I’d like to engage in some pure speculation on the speed potential of Apple’s new processors, using some back of the envelope calculations and existing <a href=\"https://browser.geekbench.com/ios-benchmarks\">GeekBench speed-test scores</a>.</p>\n<p>To get started, let’s consider the pace of Apple’s own chip development. Apple’s progress in increasing the base speed of its processors has been very consistent. That makes it fairly easy to estimate the speed of the A14 processor, which presumably will power the new iPhone models being released this fall.</p>\n<p>Did you know that the current-model Apple A13 processor generates a faster Geekbench single-core score than the fastest single-core Mac, the 2019 i9 iMac? It’s true. Now, a Geekbench score doesn’t necessarily equate to real-world speed, because every operating system can be more or less efficient. But it’s a pretty decent proxy for us to use on the back of this envelope.</p>\n<p>Assuming the normal pace of growth, that theoretical A14 processor will put that 2019 iMac to shame in terms of single-core performance. Now let’s imagine a processor designed for the Mac—I’m going to call it the M14, because why not—that’s based on the A14 but is capable of running at a higher clock speed due to active cooling systems that don’t exist on iOS. (Again, this is a guess—maybe many future Macs will be entirely fanless—but let’s go with it.) A reasonable boost, from a theoretical 3GHz M14 chip to a 3.5GHz M14 would skyrocket single-core performance.</p>\n<figure><img src=\"https://i2.wp.com/sixcolors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/silicon-speculation-single2.png?ssl=1\" alt=\"A chart full of made-up numbers.\" data-image-w=\"\" data-image-h=\"\" class=\" jetpack-broken-image\" data-recalc-dims=\"1\"><figcaption></figcaption></figure><p>That’s fun to imagine, but now let’s turn to where the rubber meets the road: multi-core performance. Again, Geekbench scores don’t tell the whole story — different operating systems behave differently when parceling out tasks to different cores. Also, Apple’s approach to multi-core processors in iOS devices is very different from the Intel processors used in Macs. Apple’s chips have two separate sets of processor cores, one set designed for high performance and the other for energy efficiency. When you really need to get work done, though, it’ll use all of them.</p>\n<p>Still, for my exercise I decided to just focus on the performance cores, because Geekbench scores really do seem to scale directly with the number of performance cores on a processor. Looking at recent trends, I again tried to extrapolate what the two-performance-core A14 processor in the next iPhone would offer, and likewise for a theoretical four-performance-core A14X processor that would power a new iPad Pro and perhaps (in some form) new Macs. Then, looking at current ratios of single-core and multi-core Geekbench scores, I imagined that my imaginary M14 processor had eight performance cores instead of four.</p>\n<figure><img src=\"https://i2.wp.com/sixcolors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/silicon-speculation-multi.png?ssl=1\" alt=\"Another speculative chart.\" data-image-w=\"\" data-image-h=\"\" class=\" jetpack-broken-image\" data-recalc-dims=\"1\"><figcaption></figcaption></figure><p>Look, this envelope is getting messy. But just consider the possibilities. Simply extrapolating the growth of the iPad Pro-class processor into the A14X generates a multi-core score that’s faster than the fastest MacBook Pro Apple currently makes.</p>\n<p>Now for giggles, toss in that eight-core “M14” processor. Now you’ve got a Mac that’s basically faster than any Intel Mac other than the very fastest Mac Pro and iMac Pro configurations.</p>\n<p>Will it happen? Who knows what Apple’s roll-out strategy will be. But if Apple wanted to use its iPad Pro-class processor in some lower-end Macs, and a souped-up processor in some higher-end Macs, it’s not unreasonable to imagine that it could blow away the performance of almost every Intel-based Mac.</p>\n<p>To repeat: These numbers are entirely made up. But going through the exercise makes me pretty confident that Apple will be able to deliver major upgrades to Mac performance.</p>\n<p>[<em>Thanks again to reader David Hovis for the suggestion.</em>]</p>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 24 Jul 2020 18:46:11 +0000","feedId":1506,"bgimg":"https://i2.wp.com/sixcolors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/silicon-speculation-single2.png?ssl=1","linkMd5":"5e12264fba6cbc0357cc4a16e4efd9a0","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn41@2020_1/2020/08/24/18-19-09-992_705555e749487293.webp","destWidth":1360,"destHeight":882,"sourceBytes":28188,"destBytes":28188,"author":"Jason Snell","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i2.wp.com/sixcolors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/silicon-speculation-single2.png?ssl=1":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn41@2020_1/2020/08/24/18-19-09-992_705555e749487293.webp","https://i2.wp.com/sixcolors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/silicon-speculation-multi.png?ssl=1":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn64@2020_6/2020/08/24/18-19-12-142_52e7fc0ef70b827b.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598293144146},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 02:19:04","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 02:19:04","title":"Viticci on the iPad as modular computer ↦","link":"http://two.wordpress.test/post/2020/04/viticci_on_the_ipad_as_modular_computer/","description":"<p>On the occasion of the tenth anniversary of the iPad shipping, it’s worth reading <a href=\"https://www.macstories.net/stories/modular-computer/\">Federico Viticci’s story about how he uses his iPad</a> today:</p>\n<blockquote><p>\n  The more I think about it, the more I come to this conclusion: the iPad, unlike other computers running a “traditional” desktop OS, possesses the unique quality of being multiple things at once. Hold an iPad in your hands, and you can use it as a classic tablet; pair it with a keyboard cover, and it takes on a laptop form; place it on a desk and connect it to a variety of external accessories, and you’ve got a desktop workstation revolving around a single slab of glass. This multiplicity of states isn’t an afterthought, nor is it the byproduct of happenstance: it was a deliberate design decision on Apple’s part based on the principle of modularity.\n</p></blockquote>\n<p>Federico pushes his iPad further than almost anyone else, but that’s okay. […] Here’s why: I didn’t get into business — I didn’t start a business — to be told what to do by another business. […] We’re self-funded. We do everything our own way so that we can do it our own way. And to be in an industry where if Apple forced us to have to give them 30% of our business and not be able to interface with our customers the way we want, I don’t want to be in that industry.\n</p></blockquote>\n<p>And here’s Reece:</p>\n<blockquote><p>\n  Even more than the latest case with Epic Games, or <a href=\"https://www.theverge.com/2020/8/22/21397424/apple-wordpress-apology-iap-free-ios-app\">WordPress iOS rejected for weeks</a>, that quote from Jason highlights what this is all about. Apple’s total control over iPhone app distribution and payment is preventing developers from doing their best work. The App Store started with good intentions, to help users, but the rules have become twisted, corrupted as Apple gains power. It’s not right.\n</p></blockquote>\n<p>I can’t tell you how many developers I’ve talked to who have similar stories.</p><p><a href=\"https://www.manton.org/2020/08/22/jason-fried-on.html\">Go to the linked site</a>.</p><p><a href=\"https://sixcolors.com/link/2020/08/i-was-considering-quitting/\">Read on Six Colors</a>.</p>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sun, 23 Aug 2020 20:29:59 +0000","feedId":1506,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"a4db78bf94da1ccf6ab4fc58f6664862","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"Jason Snell","publishedOrCreatedDate":1598293144253},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 02:19:04","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 02:19:04","title":"Laptop webcams are kind of terrible ↦","link":"http://two.wordpress.test/post/2020/04/laptop_webcams_are_kind_of_terrible/","description":"<p><a href=\"https://www.wsj.com/video/series/joanna-stern-personal-technology/webcam-showdown-macbook-air-dell-xps-theyre-pretty-bad/415D393C-4320-442B-974D-1887E20C057F\">Great video from the <em>Wall Street Journal</em>‘s Joanna Stern</a> about laptop webcams in 2020 and how they are somehow terrible, especially compared to the amazing front-facing cameras in most of our smartphones. Stern specifically calls out the brand new MacBook Air, which includes a 720p FaceTime HD camera; in some low-light conditions it’s arguably <em>worse</em> than a 2010 MacBook Pro. (Dell’s laptop camera was arguably worse, while the Pixelbook Go and Surface Laptop 3 did better in some places.)</p>\n<p>But here’s the thing: it’s not <em>just</em> the MacBook Air. The 13-inch <em>and</em> newly released 16-inch MacBook Pro both have a 720p camera, which is probably the exact same part. The tech specs for the 5K iMac say it has a “FaceTime HD camera” and don’t specify the resolution, but it says the same about the 2017 5K iMac I’m using, which definitely has a 720p camera. In fact, only <em>one</em> Mac has a webcam better than 720p—the 2017 iMac Pro, which has a 1080p camera.</p>\n<p>Meanwhile, every iPhone in the 11 series can shoot 4K video with that front-facing camera, while the XS, XR, 8, and 7 all have at least 1080p cameras on the front. The iPad Pro, iPad Air, and iPad mini all have 1080p front-facing cameras—you have to get down to the $329 iPad in order to find a mobile device with a 720p camera.</p>\n<p>As Stern says, we obviously use the front-facing cameras on our iPhones and even iPads more than we probably use the webcam on our Macs. Apple made a gamble here, arguably skimping on a component that it didn’t think most people would care about—and it might have continued to skate by on that for a while, if it hadn’t been for all of us forced into video conferencing by the coronavirus outbreak.</p>\n<p>It’ll be interesting to see if this changes in new Macs, but you shouldn’t hold your breath: unless Apple had already independently decided to upgrade the webcams, it’s likely to be quite some time before they make their way into new Macs.</p><p><a href=\"https://www.wsj.com/video/series/joanna-stern-personal-technology/webcam-showdown-macbook-air-dell-xps-theyre-pretty-bad/415D393C-4320-442B-974D-1887E20C057F\">Go to the linked site</a>.</p><p><a href=\"https://sixcolors.com/link/2020/04/laptop-webcams-are-kind-of-terrible/\">Read on Six Colors</a>.</p>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 06 Apr 2020 22:36:00 +0000","feedId":1506,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"06efcee67dd0f932de7364d643d0dffa","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"Dan Moren","publishedOrCreatedDate":1598293144543},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 02:19:04","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 02:19:04","title":"(Sponsor) Magic Lasso Adblock","link":"https://sixcolors.com/?p=12247","description":"<p>My thanks to <a href=\"https://www.magiclasso.co/\">Magic Lasso Adblock</a> for sponsoring Six Colors this week. Sometimes that’s because it’s the best way to organize information (my <a href=\"https://www.theincomparable.com/gameshow/inconceivable/\">nerdy quiz show Inconceivable!</a> has long been managed in a massive Google Spreadsheet, outstripped only by the <a href=\"https://relay.fm/clockwise\">Clockwise</a> guest spreadsheet, which is only a few episodes away from gaining sentience and attempting to absorb the world).</p>\n<p>But sometimes I’m using spreadsheets because I’m—gasp!—actually <em>working with numbers</em>. Specifically, I’m working with Numbers. Not because I have anything against Microsoft Excel<sup id=\"fnref-12129-kat\"><a href=\"https://sixcolors.com#fn-12129-kat\" class=\"jetpack-footnote\">1</a></sup>, but because Numbers is just the right speed for a word monkey like me, with its lovely charts, pretty colors, and easy to understand features.</p>\n<figure><img src=\"https://i0.wp.com/sixcolors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/cp-numbers-smartcategories-6c.jpg?ssl=1\" alt=\"Smart Categories Numbers\" data-image-w=\"\" data-image-h=\"\" class=\" jetpack-broken-image\" data-recalc-dims=\"1\"/><figcaption>Numbers’s Smart Categories feature makes it easy to view your data a different way, without destroying it.</figcaption></figure><p>One of my favorite features in Numbers, though, is a relatively recent addition: the Smart Categories feature that arrived in September 2018’s Numbers 5.2. Smart Categories is a feature that lets you quickly and (most importantly for me) non-destructively reorganize your data to view it in a different way.</p>\n<p>Smart Categories can be a little hard to find: it’s hidden under the Organize icon—the same one I <a href=\"https://sixcolors.com/member/2020/01/command-performance-off-filter/\">spoke so warmly about in Mail</a>—where it exists alongside Filter and Sort.&#8230;</p> <p>This story is for Six Colors members only. <strong><a href=\"https://sixcolors.com/subscribe/\">Become a member</a></strong> to get access to exclusive stories, podcasts, and community..</p>","descriptionType":"text/html","publishedDate":"Fri, 17 Jul 2020 19:40:48 +0000","feedId":1506,"bgimg":"https://i0.wp.com/sixcolors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/cp-numbers-smartcategories-6c.jpg?ssl=1","linkMd5":"2baedfc3ccd2e806f8530f7696f6c105","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn59@2020_4/2020/08/24/18-19-09-257_02e8af3aa733ed88.webp","destWidth":1360,"destHeight":1104,"sourceBytes":73510,"destBytes":73510,"author":"Dan Moren","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i0.wp.com/sixcolors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/cp-numbers-smartcategories-6c.jpg?ssl=1":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn59@2020_4/2020/08/24/18-19-09-257_02e8af3aa733ed88.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598293144157},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 02:19:04","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 02:19:04","title":"GitHub iOS app adds in-app purchase ↦","link":"https://sixcolors.com/?p=14549","description":"<p>If you’re wondering if <a href=\"https://sixcolors.com/link/2020/08/apple-apologizes-for-botched-wordpress-rejection/\">App Review’s approach to WordPress</a> was an isolated incident, I point you to the release notes to a recent <a href=\"https://apps.apple.com/us/app/github/id1477376905\">GitHub app update</a>:</p>\n<blockquote><p>\n  Improvements:<br>\n  • Updated design of repositories on the Home tab.<br>\n  • Introducing a new sidebar-style layout for iPad. To enable it, go to settings under Feature Preview.<br>\n  • New “marked as draft” timeline event for pull requests<br>\n  • Buy a GitHub Pro membership directly from the application\n</p></blockquote>\n<p>That last item… can’t be a coincidence, can it?</p><p><a href=\"https://apps.apple.com/us/app/github/id1477376905\">Go to the linked site</a>.</p><p><a href=\"https://sixcolors.com/link/2020/08/github-ios-app-adds-in-app-purchase/\">Read on Six Colors</a>.</p>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sun, 23 Aug 2020 20:02:22 +0000","feedId":1506,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"7aadeae3b3c6aa64f95e27b35f0d356c","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"Jason Snell","publishedOrCreatedDate":1598293144160},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 02:19:04","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 02:19:04","title":"The iPhone of the near future could have no ports (Macworld/Dan Moren)","link":"http://two.wordpress.test/post/2020/02/the_iphone_of_the_near-future_could_have_no_ports/","description":"<p>At the end of last year, rumors began to circulate that Apple was investigating the possibility of <a href=\"https://www.macworld.com/article/3487682/evaluating-the-rumors-of-the-2020-and-2021-iphones.html\">developing an iPhone with no ports at all</a>, which could see the light of day as early as 2021.</p>\n<p>To long-time Apple watchers, this wasn’t out of the blue. The company has made it clear over the past several decades that it wants to minimize and standardize the ports on its devices. Hence, bundling more and more peripheral connections into a single cable like Thunderbolt, which of course uses the same connector as the burgeoning USB-C protocol.</p>\n<p>But going portless entirely? The company has already done so on devices like the Apple Watch or the HomePod. Surely, though, the iPhone will always need a port. Or will it? More recently, it’s started to seem as though this speculation isn’t as far-fetched as some have initially thought.</p><p><a href=\"https://www.macworld.com/article/3529890/portless-iphone.html\">Continue reading on Macworld</a>.</p>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 28 Feb 2020 13:33:22 +0000","feedId":1506,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"fcdf31b7c14dbd509adbe4968c9768bc","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"Dan Moren","publishedOrCreatedDate":1598293144615},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 02:19:04","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 02:19:04","title":"How to stream games with your friends (and other things too)","link":"http://two.wordpress.test/post/2020/03/how_to_stream_games_with_your_friends_and_other_things_too/","description":"<p>Even in this age of social distancing, we still need human contact. As someone who’s worked from home for 14 years–and lived alone for much of that time–I’m more than familiar with having to come up with ways to stay in touch with friends even when we can’t get together.</p>\n<p>One thing we’ve been doing over at <a href=\"http://theincomparable.com\">The Incomparable</a>–in addition to <a href=\"http://theincomparable.com/tpk\">playing a whole ton of D&#38;D</a>–is playing games online that we stream live for our listeners.</p>\n<p>A few people have asked what my setup is for these games, in particular the <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9Aq1rwQL-z8\">Jackbox sessions</a> we occasionally do, so I’m going to run down how I make it work. Note that my method is a little complex and very specific to me, and there are definitely other–and probably easier–ways to make it work. Where possible, I’ll mention alternatives, but this isn’t intended to be an exhaustive examination–just an explanation of how I do it.</p>\n<h2>Play</h2>\n<p>Jackbox Games’s <a href=\"https://jackboxgames.com/games/\">Jackbox Party Packs</a> are collections of delightful little mini games, usually intended for a bunch of folks clustered around a single game console. But they adapt pretty well to online play, thanks in large part to the fact that, besides the person hosting the game, other players need only access to a browser, regardless of whether it’s on a computer, tablet, or phone.</p>\n<figure><img src=\"https://i2.wp.com/sixcolors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/streaming-jackbox-6c.jpg?ssl=1\" alt=\"Jackbox Games\" data-image-w=\"\" data-image-h=\"\" class=\" jetpack-broken-image\" data-recalc-dims=\"1\"><figcaption></figcaption></figure><p>I own five of the Jackbox Party Packs on my Xbox One, which is definitely not the ideal setup for streaming with friends who <em>aren’t</em> on Xbox. (Microsoft actually has pretty solid built-in tools to stream games via Mixer, which it now owns. If you’re only playing with people on that platform, it’s by far the easiest and best option. There’s also a Twitch app on Xbox which is reportedly pretty easy to use as well.)</p>\n<p>However, I’m streaming with folks who are on a variety of different devices, so I use my iMac to stream. Again, it would be much easier if I simply owned the Jackbox games, which are available on most common platforms, on my Mac. But I’m bought in on the Xbox, so that’s what I have to work with.</p>\n<h2>Capture</h2>\n<p>So, the first challenge is getting those games from my Xbox onto my Mac, so I can, in fact, stream them. For this I use an older version of an Elgato capture box, the Game Capture HD. The one I own<sup id=\"fnref-10841-appletv\"><a href=\"https://sixcolors.com#fn-10841-appletv\" class=\"jetpack-footnote\">1</a></sup> isn’t for sale anymore, but frankly, that’s fine because the newer models that Elgato sells are better. If I were buying a new box today, I’d pick up <a href=\"https://www.elgato.com/en/gaming/game-capture-hd60-s-plus\">the HD60 S+</a>, which supports up to 1080p at 60 frames per second. (There’s a 4K version that is considerably more expensive, as well as internal capture cards which would require a PC or a Mac Pro.)</p>\n<p>Most of these capture devices work on roughly the same principle: plug the HDMI from your game console into one end, plug an HDMI cable from the other end back into the TV, so the capture box essentially sits in the middle, intercepting the signal. Then plug a USB cable into your Mac, fire up Elgato’s Game Capture HD software (or some other supported software) and you’ll be able to see the game in a window on your computer.</p>\n<figure><img src=\"https://i2.wp.com/sixcolors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/streaming-gamecapturehd-6c.jpg?ssl=1\" alt=\"Game Capture HD\" data-image-w=\"\" data-image-h=\"\" class=\" jetpack-broken-image\" data-recalc-dims=\"1\"><figcaption></figcaption></figure><p>One of the downsides to having an older version of this hardware is that my only option on the software side is Elgato’s program–third-party software no longer supports or recognizes my game capture box. So I’m locked in to using Game Capture HD which, while serviceable, has its limitations. (More on which in a bit.)</p>\n<h2>Share</h2>\n<p>Okay, so I’ve got the game on my computer. Now to share it with my fellow players so they can see the screen while we’re playing. Like most of the world, I’ve been using video conferencing software <a href=\"https://zoom.us\">Zoom</a> to keep in touch with friends and family as well as recording podcasts. (This is what we’ve been using for Total Party Kill on The Incomparable for a while now.) That said, you don’t strictly <em>need</em> everybody to broadcast their camera for a game like this; as long as your players can see the screen, they only need to provide audio.</p>\n<p>However, you do need communication software that supports a) multiple people and b) screen sharing. Zoom works well for this, and it does have a free plan, though it’s not without its limitations. (Most crucially that it has a 40-minute limit on group calls.) Skype should work as well, although, full disclosure, I haven’t tried it in this workflow.</p>\n<p>Zoom also has the benefit of providing software that lets you not only share your screen but also your computer’s audio, which in games  like Jackbox, which have a lot of audio cues (and amusing dialogue), is pretty necessary. You could also use a piece of software like Rogue Amoeba’s <a href=\"https://rogueamoeba.com/loopback/\">Loopback</a> to create a virtual interface that meshes the game audio with your own mic input (assuming you’re participating in the game and not just hosting it).</p>\n<figure><img src=\"https://i0.wp.com/sixcolors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/streaming-zoom-6c.jpg?ssl=1\" alt=\"Zoom screen capture\" data-image-w=\"\" data-image-h=\"\" class=\" jetpack-broken-image\" data-recalc-dims=\"1\"><figcaption>Zoom lets you share one window off your screen; just remember to check the “Share computer sound” box if you need audio.</figcaption></figure><p>A few notes about using Zoom: first, you may need to configure it to show both your screen and your camera (again, assuming that you want or need your camera as well). Play with the Preferences &#62; General settings for Dual Displays or Side-by-Side Mode if it doesn’t seem to be working at first. For other systems, you might need to rely on a piece of software like <a href=\"http://camtwiststudio.com\">CamTwist</a>, which can let you merge multiple video sources into one.</p>\n<p>Second, since I’m sharing the Game Capture HD window, it means my players also see the sidebar of controls in that app. Though you can hide it using the View menu, it automatically–and annoyingly–appears whenever you mouse over the window. You could in theory fullscreen Game Capture HD, which also hides it in a separate space, but then you can’t see the game on the same screen as your video chat, and Zoom’s screen sharing seems to pause when you’re sharing from a separate space. Alternatively, you could capture just a portion of your screen, but be aware that if you move the window, another app overlaps on the game screen, or you use something like Mission Control, it will disrupt your screen sharing.</p>\n<p>And do be aware that, no matter what you do, both the capture and sharing via Zoom add some degree of delay to the game. While this is generally okay in games like Jackbox, it’s not really suitable for anything that requires fast reaction times. (Even in Jackbox, it’s worth turning on the Extended Timer options most of the games have, and reminding your players that the countdown timer they see is probably a few seconds behind the actual time.)</p>\n<h2>Stream</h2>\n<p>The game is coming into your Mac and all your players can (hopefully) see it. Now, how do you get your game out to the masses? Well, Elgato’s Game Capture HD does have built-in streaming that works pretty well and even allows you to layer over game commentary…and wouldn’t it be nice if that were the answer. Unfortunately, since Game Capture HD serves as both the input <em>and</em> output, trying to pipe audio from the game to the Zoom call, and then send it out again results in a whole lot of feedback.<sup id=\"fnref-10841-audioshenanigans\"><a href=\"https://sixcolors.com#fn-10841-audioshenanigans\" class=\"jetpack-footnote\">2</a></sup></p>\n<p>So instead, I fell back to another piece of software that we use for TPK: Telestream’s <a href=\"http://www.telestream.net/wirecast/overview.htm\">Wirecast</a>. Wirecast is an extremely powerful piece of software that allows you to stream to one (or more) places, including YouTube and Twitch.</p>\n<figure><img src=\"https://i0.wp.com/sixcolors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/streaming-wirecast-6c.jpg?ssl=1\" alt=\"Wirecast\" data-image-w=\"\" data-image-h=\"\" class=\" jetpack-broken-image\" data-recalc-dims=\"1\"><figcaption>Wirecast is a powerful–but pricey–piece of streaming software.</figcaption></figure><p>I use Wirecast’s screen capture features to grab the Game Capture HD window, just as I do in Zoom. You may remember that I had problems with capturing the sidebar for my players–the good news is that Wirecast makes it easy to scale and crop the screen capture, so that only the portion of the screen you want is sent to the stream.</p>\n<p>That said, Wirecast is very expensive, especially if you’re just looking for a way to relax with your friends. While perhaps not as user friendly, the open source <a href=\"https://obsproject.com\">OBS Studio</a> offers a lot of the same features for free, and is probably a much better choice for most folks.</p>\n<p>There’s also a service named <a href=\"https://streamyard.com/\">Streamyard</a> that some folks have recommended; it has both paid and free plans, though the latter has more limitations. I don’t have any personal experience with it, so can’t speak to its utility.</p>\n<h2>Conclusion</h2>\n<p>Not everybody needs all of the above steps. Some might just want to get together on a chat program like Zoom or Skype and play a game. Others might want to stream a Zoom chat live. You can mix and match these various steps to get the parts and tools you need.</p>\n<p>The most important thing about all of this is that it’s a great way to bring people together. Even in this time of isolation, the best way to deal with these things is together.</p>\n<div class=\"footnotes\">\n<hr><ol><li id=\"fn-10841-appletv\">\nOriginally purchased by my former employer when there was no way to get high quality captures of the Apple TV interface without this kind of hardware. <a href=\"https://sixcolors.com#fnref-10841-appletv\"><img src=\"https://s.w.org/images/core/emoji/13.0.0/72x72/21a9.png\" alt=\"↩\" class=\"wp-smiley\" style=\"height: 1em; max-height: 1em;\" /></a>\n</li>\n<li id=\"fn-10841-audioshenanigans\">\nIt’s possible there is a simpler way to do this using Loopback or some other audio routing software, but I definitely haven’t figured it out yet. <a href=\"https://sixcolors.com#fnref-10841-audioshenanigans\"><img src=\"https://s.w.org/images/core/emoji/13.0.0/72x72/21a9.png\" alt=\"↩\" class=\"wp-smiley\" style=\"height: 1em; However, it does solve a fundamental problem that the Shortcuts app has had since it was called Workflow: A complete lack of ability to filter the shortcuts list, which can get out of control in a hurry.</p>\n<p>I tend to run most of my Shortcuts from the Share sheet or via a widget, but whenever I am creating or editing Shortcuts, I have to drift slowly through the largely unordered Shortcuts interface to find what I want. It’s something that Apple should’ve addressed already, but at least LaunchCuts provides a clever hack to simplify things in the meantime for those who have more than a couple dozen shortcuts.</p>\n<p>(<a href=\"https://apps.apple.com/us/app/launchcuts/id1489780246?uo=4\">LaunchCuts</a> is available in the App Store.)</p><p><a href=\"https://www.macstories.net/reviews/launchcuts-review-a-better-way-to-organize-your-shortcuts-with-folders-advanced-search-and-custom-views/\">Go to the linked site</a>.</p><p><a href=\"https://sixcolors.com/link/2020/01/launchcuts-a-launcher-for-shortcuts/\">Read on Six Colors</a>.</p>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Wed, 08 Jan 2020 08:42:59 +0000","feedId":1506,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"8a8f720f3dba66bb6a7c7cb1a07f71f5","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"Jason Snell","publishedOrCreatedDate":1598293144657},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 02:19:04","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 02:19:04","title":"(Podcast) The Rebound 294: It’s For Horses","link":"https://sixcolors.com/?p=11370","description":"<p>It’s the week before WWDC so it’s the perfect time for Apple to have a fight with developers.</p><p><a href=\"http://reboundcast.com/episode/294\">Go to the podcast page</a>.</p>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Wed, 17 Jun 2020 18:11:30 +0000","feedId":1506,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"fb945af9a583e7ade9bd59114ad39024","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"Dan Moren","publishedOrCreatedDate":1598293144218},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 02:19:04","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 02:19:04","title":"WWDC 2020: The little stuff you might have missed","link":"https://sixcolors.com/?p=11492","description":"<p>As always, Apple’s WWDC keynote was jam-packed with more jam than a packing plant full of jam. We all saw the big top line items: Macs switching to ARM, iOS apps running on the Mac, cats and dogs living together. But the sheer loudness of that news drowned a host of other little interesting tidbits that are significant in their own right. Here are just a few of the ones that caught my eye.</p>\n<h2>Tap tap revolution</h2>\n<blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\">\n<p dir=\"ltr\" lang=\"en\"><a href=\"https://twitter.com/hashtag/iOS14?src=hash&#38;ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">#iOS14</a> Back Tap: Double or triple tap the back of your iPhone to perform some actions quickly <img src=\"https://s.w.org/images/core/emoji/13.0.0/72x72/1f62f.png\" alt=\"😯\" class=\"wp-smiley\" style=\"height: 1em; max-height: 1em;\" /> <a href=\"https://t.co/HIsvnHusKz\">pic.twitter.com/HIsvnHusKz</a></p>\n<p>— Ben Geskin (@BenGeskin) <a href=\"https://twitter.com/BenGeskin/status/1275206369755398145?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">June 22, 2020</a></p></blockquote>\n<p><script async src=\"https://platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"></script></p>\n<p>As a new Accessibility option, <a href=\"https://twitter.com/bengeskin/status/1275206369755398145\">iOS 14 allows you to trigger actions by double- or triple-tapping the back of your phone</a>. While this is definitely useful for people for whom the touch screen is unwieldy, it also has surprisingly big implications for all users, in that Apple hasn’t really allowed you to define systemwide actions before.</p>\n<p>Federico Viticci <a href=\"https://twitter.com/viticci/status/1275237131477270530\">reports that you can even use this action to trigger a custom shortcut</a>, which is kind of wild. Given how many Apple features have showed up as Accessibility options before becoming more robust features—hello, cursor support—it makes me wonder if this might be a harbinger of some more in-depth systemwide capabilities in a future version of iOS.<sup id=\"fnref-11492-morse\"><a href=\"https://sixcolors.com#fn-11492-morse\" class=\"jetpack-footnote\">1</a></sup></p>\n<h2>App Store review process, reviewed</h2>\n<p>Even after last week’s high profile clash between the developers of email app Hey and Apple’s App Store review process, there was skepticism from many quarters—including yours truly—that Apple would do anything to address the weaknesses in its relationship with developers. And while the company remained mum during its keynote, <a href=\"https://www.apple.com/newsroom/2020/06/apple-reveals-new-developer-technologies-to-foster-the-next-generation-of-apps/\">it did announce that it would be making a couple of high profile changes</a>.</p>\n<p>First, developers can now not only challenge whether or not their app actually violates an App Store guideline, but they can also <em>challenge the guideline itself</em>.<sup id=\"fnref-11492-attack\"><a href=\"https://sixcolors.com#fn-11492-attack\" class=\"jetpack-footnote\">2</a></sup> Of course, this means absolutely nothing until we see how the process actually works, but the possibility of overturning an App Store guideline is wild. This is like Apple creating a Supreme Court of App Review. (Though let’s not be too altruistic: I’m sure Apple hopes that it will short circuit the current process of going public, thus potentially saving them the bad PR of having people yelling about the issues on Twitter.)</p>\n<p>Second, Apple says it will no longer hold up bug fix updates because of App Store review guidelines. Frankly, this should have always been the case—not only was this a bad policy for developers, but it was actively user-hostile, forcing customers into two bad options: keep using apps with annoying or potentially serious bugs or stop using the app altogether, all because of bureaucratic guidelines.</p>\n<p>While these are moves in the right direction, I doubt they will be enough to stave off the government inquiries that are already underway, nor earn back all the goodwill that the company has burned with developers.</p>\n<h2>The Force will not always be with you</h2>\n<p>Apple effectively killed 3D Touch last year by replacing it with the haptic touch feature in the iPhone 11 line, but it looks like its old-friend/the-same-exact-feature-with-a-different-name Force Touch is not long for the world either. <a href=\"https://www.macrumors.com/2020/06/23/apple-drops-force-touch-gesture-in-watchos-7/\">MacRumors reports that watchOS 7 is shifting developers away from using the Force Touch interaction</a>, in favor of exposing those features in other ways.</p>\n<p>Gotta say, I’m not broken up about that. Force Touch was clever, but too often it concealed features that were not easily discoverable. Moreover, I’m sure the technology to detect those harder presses took up space in the Apple Watch that could have been used for other things—battery, for example, or just making the Watch slimmer.</p>\n<p>My question is, now that Force Touch/3D Touch are gone on the Watch and on future iPhones, will it also quietly be phased out on the Mac? (That is, if anybody even remembers that it’s actually there in the first place…)</p>\n<h2>Never taken a Shortcut before?</h2>\n<p>Apple’s Shortcuts automation system got very little time on stage (what there was was mostly linked to the new Wind Down feature), but the app itself did get <a href=\"https://twitter.com/viticci/status/1275172195497623552\">a number of useful enhancements</a>, including folders, copy and pasting actions within shortcuts, new automation triggers, <em>and</em> running Shortcuts on the Apple Watch, including triggering them from complications on the watch face.</p>\n<blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\">\n<p dir=\"ltr\" lang=\"en\">Shortcuts got some very cool updates in iOS/iPadOS 14:</p>\n<p>– Folders<br>\n– Disable confirmation for automations<br>\n– New compact UI for lists, input dialogs, running shortcuts in share sheet<br>\n– Automatic categories for share sheet/Watch<br>\n– Copy &#38; paste actions (!)<br>\n– New automation triggers <a href=\"https://t.co/8j4iZ0pyks\">pic.twitter.com/8j4iZ0pyks</a></p>\n<p>— Federico Viticci (@viticci) <a href=\"https://twitter.com/viticci/status/1275172195497623552?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">June 22, 2020</a></p></blockquote>\n<p><script async src=\"https://platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"></script></p>\n<p>These changes make Shortcuts even more useful for its most devoted users. It warms the cockles of my heart to see Apple continue to invest in the power and utility of Shortcuts, even if it doesn’t give them much time in front of the keynote audience.</p>\n<h2>Other feature tidbits</h2>\n<p>iOS 14 has <a href=\"https://twitter.com/gregbarbosa/status/1275188696296325121\">a very cool new Accessibility feature that can recognize certain sounds</a>, like fire alarms and animals, and then provide notifications to users. This is potentially amazing—and heck, life-saving—for hard-of-hearing folks who might otherwise not catch these sounds.</p>\n<p>There’s now <a href=\"https://twitter.com/gregbarbosa/status/1275187584864526336\">an NFC reader button in Control Center</a>.</p>\n<p><a href=\"https://twitter.com/kvanh/status/1275261658030649344\">Game Center got a refresh</a>! Who had that one on the bingo card?!</p>\n<p><a href=\"https://twitter.com/dmoren/status/1275145437696188421\">EMOJI SEARCH ON iOS</a>.</p>\n<p>I’m sure there’s plenty more out there that hasn’t been uncovered, not to mention all the myriad sessions coming this week. But don’t worry, even though some times some things go slipping through the cracks, these two gumshoes are picking up the slack.</p>\n<div class=\"footnotes\">\n<hr><ol><li id=\"fn-11492-morse\">\nReally looking forward to launching an app by tapping its name in Morse code on the back of my phone. <a href=\"https://sixcolors.com#fnref-11492-morse\"><img src=\"https://s.w.org/images/core/emoji/13.0.0/72x72/21a9.png\" alt=\"↩\" class=\"wp-smiley\" style=\"height: 1em;
